Home Anime What to Expect From Requiem of the Rose King's Darker Second Cour    What to Expect From Requiem of the Rose King's Darker Second Cour  By Hilary Leung Published 19 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The second cour of the Shakespearean anime will be much more intense than the first.                 The following contains spoilers for the first cour of Requiem of the Rose King, now streaming on Funimation.The first cour of Requiem of the Rose King ended on a dismal note. Having his heart broken multiple times by those he loved the most, Richard stabbed Henry until all of the words, cursing him as a demon, finally stopped. The episode ends with Richard embracing his new and darker beginnings after leaving the old Richard, who yearned to be loved, for dead in the forest. It's a tragic ending, and it only speaks to even darker beginnings as the second cour of the anime begins.  In the next part of Requiem of the Rose King, viewers are about to see a different side of Richard. While his goal has always been to protect the House of York and for York to be the ones in power, he is starting to take every measure possible to ensure that this is the case -- even if that means going against his brothers. New characters will be introduced and more conspiracies will be hatched behind the scenes to gain control of the throne. Here's what viewers should know going in. RELATED: Requiem of the Rose King's Biggest Identity Reveals Land [SPOILER] in Hell          Time-Skip in Requiem of the Rose King                 A few years have passed since the events of the first cour, and several things have come to pass. The first is that Richard and Anne have since married. Once upon a time, the two of them marrying would have been a happy occasion since the two genuinely seemed to like each other. However, with Richard misunderstanding Anne's words and Anne witnessing Richard kill Edward and hearing how he did the same to her father, their marriage is a loveless one. Anne has also given birth to Edward's child, who adores Richard. Meanwhile, Edward and Elizabeth's marriage has grown stale. Once infatuated with the Woodville widow, Edward now seeks comfort in other women's arms. Elizabeth isn't too bothered by it though; her plan to seize control of the throne to avenge her husband's death has already been set into motion with the birth of her two sons. All she needs to do is bide her time.          A Witch and Assassin Get Introduced                 Aside from the main cast of characters such as Richard, his brothers and Anne, the second cour will introduce some new characters, one of whom is a witch named Jane Shore who is revealed to be a lascivious and seductive woman, capable of turning men weak with her potions. A shockingly familiar face also makes his appearance in the form of a merciless assassin named James Tyrell. He has no memories of his past life and one of his eyes is slashed. When he's not carrying out his assassinations, Tyrell spends his time shepherding, which sounds eerily familiar to another man viewers have met before.  RELATED: Yashahime Season 2's Biggest Unanswered Questions          The Power Struggle for the Throne                 The king's crown is never free of blood. Richard's father was slain. Warwick was killed after he became regent. A war among brothers almost broke out after George betrayed Edward. Henry's son was killed by Richard. After all the bloody conflicts, the crown now rests on Edward's head. Even though Edward and George had reconciled and it looked like they were genuinely back to being loyal brothers, the latter still seeks the crown for himself. After the time skip, George has been drowning himself in alcohol, making him reckless.  Buckingham had always seen a king's quality within Richard, even though he was insistent that he only sought to serve the House of York and its interests. However, Buckingham knew that deep down, Richard desired the crown for himself. But before Richard can sit on the throne, he'll need to clear everyone in his way, which includes his brothers, their heirs and a new rival: the Duke of Richmond.           The Darker Undertones of the Story                 Richard's internal struggle has always been the point of conflict within the story. Having spent his life being derided for his body and being rejected, it didn't look like he would ever be accepted by anyone he loved, especially after losing Henry. However, he does find someone who will love and accept him for who he is -- his other half -- but the beginning of their relationship is fraught with its own issues and tensions. Richard's path to kingship will not be an easy one. The higher he climbs, the more despair he seems to sink under.  Requiem of the Rose King isn't a lighthearted series. It deals with sex and violence that is closely intertwined with the politics of the story. The anime adaptation hasn't been as explicit in these particular scenes and has only been heavily implied. The second cour will only become darker and more serious from here on out, although whether the anime adaptation will be faithful to the manga in that regard remains to be seen. Home Anime What to Expect From Requiem of the Rose King's Darker Second Cour    What to Expect From Requiem of the Rose King's Darker Second Cour  By Hilary Leung Published 19 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The second cour of the Shakespearean anime will be much more intense than the first.                 The following contains spoilers for the first cour of Requiem of the Rose King, now streaming on Funimation.The first cour of Requiem of the Rose King ended on a dismal note. Having his heart broken multiple times by those he loved the most, Richard stabbed Henry until all of the words, cursing him as a demon, finally stopped. The episode ends with Richard embracing his new and darker beginnings after leaving the old Richard, who yearned to be loved, for dead in the forest. It's a tragic ending, and it only speaks to even darker beginnings as the second cour of the anime begins.  In the next part of Requiem of the Rose King, viewers are about to see a different side of Richard. While his goal has always been to protect the House of York and for York to be the ones in power, he is starting to take every measure possible to ensure that this is the case -- even if that means going against his brothers. New characters will be introduced and more conspiracies will be hatched behind the scenes to gain control of the throne. Here's what viewers should know going in. RELATED: Requiem of the Rose King's Biggest Identity Reveals Land [SPOILER] in Hell          Time-Skip in Requiem of the Rose King                 A few years have passed since the events of the first cour, and several things have come to pass. The first is that Richard and Anne have since married. Once upon a time, the two of them marrying would have been a happy occasion since the two genuinely seemed to like each other. However, with Richard misunderstanding Anne's words and Anne witnessing Richard kill Edward and hearing how he did the same to her father, their marriage is a loveless one. Anne has also given birth to Edward's child, who adores Richard. Meanwhile, Edward and Elizabeth's marriage has grown stale. Once infatuated with the Woodville widow, Edward now seeks comfort in other women's arms. Elizabeth isn't too bothered by it though; her plan to seize control of the throne to avenge her husband's death has already been set into motion with the birth of her two sons. All she needs to do is bide her time.          A Witch and Assassin Get Introduced                 Aside from the main cast of characters such as Richard, his brothers and Anne, the second cour will introduce some new characters, one of whom is a witch named Jane Shore who is revealed to be a lascivious and seductive woman, capable of turning men weak with her potions. A shockingly familiar face also makes his appearance in the form of a merciless assassin named James Tyrell. He has no memories of his past life and one of his eyes is slashed. When he's not carrying out his assassinations, Tyrell spends his time shepherding, which sounds eerily familiar to another man viewers have met before.  RELATED: Yashahime Season 2's Biggest Unanswered Questions          The Power Struggle for the Throne                 The king's crown is never free of blood. Richard's father was slain. Warwick was killed after he became regent. A war among brothers almost broke out after George betrayed Edward. Henry's son was killed by Richard. After all the bloody conflicts, the crown now rests on Edward's head. Even though Edward and George had reconciled and it looked like they were genuinely back to being loyal brothers, the latter still seeks the crown for himself. After the time skip, George has been drowning himself in alcohol, making him reckless.  Buckingham had always seen a king's quality within Richard, even though he was insistent that he only sought to serve the House of York and its interests. However, Buckingham knew that deep down, Richard desired the crown for himself. But before Richard can sit on the throne, he'll need to clear everyone in his way, which includes his brothers, their heirs and a new rival: the Duke of Richmond.           The Darker Undertones of the Story                 Richard's internal struggle has always been the point of conflict within the story. Having spent his life being derided for his body and being rejected, it didn't look like he would ever be accepted by anyone he loved, especially after losing Henry. However, he does find someone who will love and accept him for who he is -- his other half -- but the beginning of their relationship is fraught with its own issues and tensions. Richard's path to kingship will not be an easy one. The higher he climbs, the more despair he seems to sink under.  Requiem of the Rose King isn't a lighthearted series. It deals with sex and violence that is closely intertwined with the politics of the story. The anime adaptation hasn't been as explicit in these particular scenes and has only been heavily implied. The second cour will only become darker and more serious from here on out, although whether the anime adaptation will be faithful to the manga in that regard remains to be seen. Home Comics Comic News The New Batman's Personal Joker Shows How Dangerous - and Different - He Is    The New Batman's Personal Joker Shows How Dangerous - and Different - He Is  By Jeremy Blum Published 20 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Jace Fox encounters a new masked enemy in I Am Batman #8, and this villain boasts all of the sadism of the Joker with a deadly physicality.                  Jace Fox bumps into an enemy who appears to be his personal Joker in the latest issue of I Am Batman, and while this villain may boast the same sadistic tendency towards violence as Gotham's Clown Prince of Crime, he also has a dangerous strength to him -- not to mention proficiency with an unusual weapon.  A preview of I Am Batman #8 provided by DC shows Batman confronting his red masked foe in a gallery full of art depicting bodily mutilation. The villain -- whose name appears to be "Manray," judging from the previous issue -- taunts Jace with the same language that the Joker uses against Bruce Wayne and argues that both of them are fighting for the same cause. When Jace ignores Manray's words and throws a punch, the serial killer brandishes what looks like a spiked steaming iron on a chain, slashing Jace's face and knocking him to the ground. RELATED: Deathstroke Was Never Meant To Be Batman's Equal - He's Better    7 Images                   Expand                    Expand                    Expand                    Expand                    Expand                    Expand                    Expand      Close          Thus far, Manray appears to be responsible for the grisly murder of New York philanthropist Devlin Rubel, who was dismembered, crushed and hung up like a canvas in I Am Batman #6. Issue #7 revealed that Rubel was far from a saint, and secretly engaged in sex trafficking. Manray, who seems to fancy himself an avenging vigilante in the same vein as the Dark Knight, may have used Rubel's sins as an excuse to kill him if his passionate speech to Jace is any indication. Thus far, I Am Batman's Jace Fox has mainly tackled street-level crime since moving to New York City with his mother and sisters in issue #6. Home Comics Comic Book Reviews Marvel's X-Force Annual #1 Comic Review    Marvel's X-Force Annual #1 Comic Review  By Sayantan Gayen Published 4 days ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   X-Force Annual #1 is a classic X-Force story complete with lurking threats and suspicious teammates that hits all the right notes.                                    X-Force Annual #1   Writer  Nadia Shammas    Artist  Rafael Pimentel, Carlos Lopez    Letterer  VC's Joe Caramagna    Publisher  Marvel Comics    Price  4.99    Release Date  2022-04-06      Since its inception, X-Force has been touted as the black ops X-Men team that is usually delegated to handle all kinds of dirty work. For tasks that the X-Men can't or won't deal with, X-Force and its ragtag collection of less than savory, violence-loving characters usually get the job done. In the current world order, where Krakoa has redefined mutants as a force in the Marvel universe, X-Force remains the same but feels different. Its biggest threats come from its own teammates, especially Beast, who has lately been showing a frivolous disregard for the lives of pretty much anyone. Written by Nadia Shammas with artwork from Rafael Pimentel and Carlos Lopez and lettering by VC's Joe Caramagna, X-Force Annual #1 tells a story that continues ongoing arcs while developing the shady and distrustful dynamic that saturates this team.  X-Force Annual #1 follows the current X-Force team of Wolverine, Domino, and Quire as they are sent out on a covert mission to deal with a potential superweapon by Beast. On paper, it seems like your standard X-Force mission: get in, take out some bad guys, stop the weapon, and get out. Intel suggests that the Orchis have managed to steal a shipment from Hellfire Trading. As the mission progresses, it becomes clear that things aren't what they appear to be. The team starts to feel like maybe Beast has led them into a trap, but it's not clear why. RELATED: Marvel's Devil's Reign #6 Comic Review                  Nadia Shammas has a good handle on how each character of this ensemble cast responds and reacts to each other and their world. She shows off her good grasp of X-Men history and writing chops by creating a tense, suspicious atmosphere. The occasional well-placed bit of humor brings some much-needed levity to the book, as well. A pure highlight of this issue is Beast and Emma’s conversation, which wonderfully showcases just how far gone the once-lovable blue boy has become. Emma asks some pointed questions, and Beast expertly "addresses" them, though the results of this conversation are something that the writer keeps close to her chest. Anticipation like this builds towards a feeling of dread and excitement in equal measure, leaving the reader wondering just what weaknesses Beast can exploit out of this situation.  Rafael Pimentel's art and Carlos Lopez's colors work well to bring this adventure to life. Each character is distinctly and instantly identifiable by their silhouettes and colors. Wolverine, in particular, is drawn as stocky and thick, harkening back to his original stature and energy, which is something a lot of recent iterations tend to forget. This is an X-Men book through and through in all its colorful, weird glory, with Pimentel and Lopez determined to make readers see that in every frame. Though there are some slight hiccups here and there with some awkward art and stiff character movement, the overall look of the book is still great.  RELATED: Marvel's Marauders #1 Comic Review                 In this ever-expanding story of "What will Beast do next?" X-Force Annual #1 manages to ask the more serious questions about Beast's motivations. A great setup scene with '90s action drives the story into a far more nefarious arc once it reaches its conclusion. Nadia Shammas carries forward the torch left by her predecessor, Benjamin Percy, and absolutely runs with it. Beast may not be evil per se, but his complete disregard for the individual lives of his teammates in his pursuit of the greater good is a worrying precedent, one that rightfully builds suspicion from his peers. What happens next remains to be seen, but X-Force Annual #1 stands as a testament to the spirit of fun and suspense that X-Men comics hold. X-Force Annual #1   Writer  Nadia Shammas    Artist  Rafael Pimentel, Carlos Lopez    Letterer  VC's Joe Caramagna    Publisher  Marvel Comics    Price  4.99    Release Date  2022-04-06      Since its inception, X-Force has been touted as the black ops X-Men team that is usually delegated to handle all kinds of dirty work. For tasks that the X-Men can't or won't deal with, X-Force and its ragtag collection of less than savory, violence-loving characters usually get the job done. In the current world order, where Krakoa has redefined mutants as a force in the Marvel universe, X-Force remains the same but feels different. Its biggest threats come from its own teammates, especially Beast, who has lately been showing a frivolous disregard for the lives of pretty much anyone. Written by Nadia Shammas with artwork from Rafael Pimentel and Carlos Lopez and lettering by VC's Joe Caramagna, X-Force Annual #1 tells a story that continues ongoing arcs while developing the shady and distrustful dynamic that saturates this team.  X-Force Annual #1 follows the current X-Force team of Wolverine, Domino, and Quire as they are sent out on a covert mission to deal with a potential superweapon by Beast. On paper, it seems like your standard X-Force mission: get in, take out some bad guys, stop the weapon, and get out. Intel suggests that the Orchis have managed to steal a shipment from Hellfire Trading. As the mission progresses, it becomes clear that things aren't what they appear to be. The team starts to feel like maybe Beast has led them into a trap, but it's not clear why. RELATED: Marvel's Devil's Reign #6 Comic Review                  Nadia Shammas has a good handle on how each character of this ensemble cast responds and reacts to each other and their world. She shows off her good grasp of X-Men history and writing chops by creating a tense, suspicious atmosphere. The occasional well-placed bit of humor brings some much-needed levity to the book, as well. A pure highlight of this issue is Beast and Emma’s conversation, which wonderfully showcases just how far gone the once-lovable blue boy has become. Emma asks some pointed questions, and Beast expertly "addresses" them, though the results of this conversation are something that the writer keeps close to her chest. Anticipation like this builds towards a feeling of dread and excitement in equal measure, leaving the reader wondering just what weaknesses Beast can exploit out of this situation.  Rafael Pimentel's art and Carlos Lopez's colors work well to bring this adventure to life. Each character is distinctly and instantly identifiable by their silhouettes and colors. Wolverine, in particular, is drawn as stocky and thick, harkening back to his original stature and energy, which is something a lot of recent iterations tend to forget. This is an X-Men book through and through in all its colorful, weird glory, with Pimentel and Lopez determined to make readers see that in every frame. Though there are some slight hiccups here and there with some awkward art and stiff character movement, the overall look of the book is still great.  RELATED: Marvel's Marauders #1 Comic Review                 In this ever-expanding story of "What will Beast do next?" X-Force Annual #1 manages to ask the more serious questions about Beast's motivations. A great setup scene with '90s action drives the story into a far more nefarious arc once it reaches its conclusion. Nadia Shammas carries forward the torch left by her predecessor, Benjamin Percy, and absolutely runs with it. Beast may not be evil per se, but his complete disregard for the individual lives of his teammates in his pursuit of the greater good is a worrying precedent, one that rightfully builds suspicion from his peers. What happens next remains to be seen, but X-Force Annual #1 stands as a testament to the spirit of fun and suspense that X-Men comics hold. Home Anime Science Fell in Love Teases Its Newest Romance    Science Fell in Love Teases Its Newest Romance  By Louis Kemner Published 17 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   In Season 2 Episode 2 of Science Fell in Love, Kosuke and Ena grow closer than ever behind the scenes as a potential new couple.                  The following contains spoilers for Season 2, Episode 2 of Science Fell in Love, So I Tried to Prove It, now streaming on Crunchyroll.   The charming rom-com anime series Science Fell in Love returns to the lab for another season of romantic scientist hijinks between the handsome kuudere Yukimura Shinya and the gorgeous Himuro Ayame. Just like in Season 1, these two amorous scientist students are taking center stage -- but there's more going on behind the scenes in Season 2.  Shinya and Ayame aren't alone in that lab at Saitama University. They have plenty of classmates and friends to support them, including the tiny but tough Ibarada Ena and the dating sim enthusiast Inukai Kosuke, and these two colorful scientists have more chemistry than ever as Season 2 gets underway. Just like two celestial masses, they can't help attracting one another. RELATED: Aharen-San Redefines the Possibilities of Kuudere Anime Characters                By now, Science Fell In Love can create contrast between its main couples to prove that lovestruck scientsts might develop their relationships in completely different ways. The Ayame/Shinya pair was the only one last season, but Season 2 also features the Fujiwara Suiu/Chris Florette pairing, and they follow a totally different set of rules. Instead of using reseach and tests on the science of love, Chris and Suiu simply go by feeling like anyone else would -- and Ena and Kosuke might soon follow their example.  Kosuke and Ena support the Shina/Ayame pairing but see no need to emulate what they are doing. They both know what they like and need no tests to prove it, and they may very well bond over this fact. As Episode 2 proves, they're growing closer than ever -- and they don't need oxytocin tests or charts to know it. Neither Ena nor Kosuke will admit it openly, but they have serious chemistry with one another and greatly enjoy each other's company. And anime series such as Science Fell in Love rarely tease new pairings like this without following through, meaning scientist couple #3 is surely around the corner. Fans of the first season may agree that this particular one is long overdue, which should add some spice to Season 2.  RELATED: Science Fell in Love: How Shinya & Ayame Actually Got Together in Season 1                So far, Season 2 of Science Fell in Love has only hinted at a Kosuke/Ena pairing with some suggestive winks about their feasibility, including a post-credits scene where Ayame unwittingly compares them to two celestial bodies being drawn together by gravity before settling into a comfortable shared orbit. Still, Kosuke and Ena's scenes together appear promising, with Ena finding herself unable to resist joining him for a game of off-brand Super Smash Bros., and nothing makes Kosuke happier than having her with him instead of playing against the CPU. Neither one feels satisfied unless the other is there.  If this potential couple does take off, they will most likely follow Chris and Suiu's example, proceeding with gut feelings and traditional social cues and rules rather than experiments. That would help set them apart from Ayame and Shinya, and Kosuke's and Ena's habit of gently teasing one another can further set these pairings apart to avoid redundancy. In fact, Ena and Kosuke have a subtle "battle of wits" element to their budding relationship, where these stubborn but kind young scientists are too proud to openly admit their feelings or make the first move. That actually makes Science Fell in Love's newest potential couple similar to the main couple of Kaguya-Sama: Love is War, whose third season is also airing in the Spring 2022 anime season. Fans of stubborn but charming couples are in for a double treat this season.                   Science Fell in Love: Why Did Ayame Originally Fall For Shinya? Home Anime Shield Hero: What You Should Know About the Filolial Race    Shield Hero: What You Should Know About the Filolial Race  By Louis Kemner Published 18 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   In The Rising of the Shield Hero, the avian filolials are a fascinating species found all over the kingdom of Melromarc.                 The Rising of the Shield Hero is a popular isekai animated series that returned in the Spring 2022 anime season for more otherworldly mayhem. There's a lot to keep track of as Season 2 begins, including a few exotic species and races. New and returning fans alike might want to brush up on who's who and what's what in this ever-expanding universe.  For example, there are demi-humans with animal tails and ears, such as the tanuki girl Raphtalia, as well as the avian filolial race, to which the colorful character Filo belongs. A variety of filolials have appeared so far in Shield Hero, and their race could potentially play a major role in deciding the future of this entire fantasy realm. RELATED: Shield Hero: Who Is the True Ruler of Melromarc?          The Biology Of The Filolial Race In Shield Hero                Filolials are intelligent avian creatures that are hatched from eggs. Like many birds, filolial hatchlings will immediately seek a parental figure and imprint it onto their minds. These animals are also directly influenced by the chocobo species in the Final Fantasy games, meaning filolials are excellent runners that can easily keep pace with horses, land dragons and other fast-moving creatures. They are capable of carrying a human rider like a horse, and can also pull ordinary wagons for hours on end. In combat they can use wind-based magic, their beaks and talon-based attacks to deal damage to their enemies.  Some filolials can transform into a human form and back again at will, and the human form's apparent age seems to reflect the filolial's actual age. When it transforms, a young filolial will look like a child with a juvenile personality and worldview to match. Filolials can even speak while in human form, and have angel-like wings on their backs as well. Notably, they will grow much larger when they transform back to bird form, so they are liable to tear their clothes apart in the process. Luckily, special clothing can be made from a filolial's hair to circumvent this issue. Finally, the filolials seen in Shield Hero are known for their community-oriented behavior, such as large numbers working in perfect unison to fight a much larger foe. In a similar vein, they can use the upright feathers on their heads to communicate telepathically from a distance.  RELATED: Meet The Rising of the Shield Hero's Main Characters          Notable Filolials In Rising of the Shield Hero                 Only two named filolials have appeared so far in The Rising of the Shield Hero, but both have a major role to play and represent their race well. The first to appear was the newly-hatched Filo, whom Naofumi simply named after her race. Filo is no ordinary filolial -- she has the potential to become a queen, and if she powers up enough, she may develop a few ahoge on her head to mark her status. She can use wind magic and melee attacks like most other filolials, and enjoys pulling Naofumi's wagon during long journeys across Melromarc. Filo views Naofumi as a mother hen and is attached to him -- to the point of making Raphtalia deeply jealous. Despite that, she and Raphtalia get along like foster sisters in Naofumi's party.  The other major filolial seen so far is the queen herself, Fitoria. She has three ahoge on her head to mark her authority and magical power, and she is deeply invested in the Shield Hero's success against the Waves. However, Fitoria can also be demanding and ruthless, stating that if Naofumi cannot reconcile with the other three Cardinal Heroes as a team, Fitoria will simply kill them all and allow four replacement heroes to be summoned. In Fitoria's eyes, protecting the world is vastly more important than the personal feud between the Cardinal Heroes -- or their lives. Fitoria will support Naofumi and Filo for now, but if they fail her, they might pay for it with their lives. Rising of the Shield Hero's queen has no time for games. She has three ahoge on her head to mark her authority and magical power, and she is deeply invested in the Shield Hero's success against the Waves. However, Fitoria can also be demanding and ruthless, stating that if Naofumi cannot reconcile with the other three Cardinal Heroes as a team, Fitoria will simply kill them all and allow four replacement heroes to be summoned. In Fitoria's eyes, protecting the world is vastly more important than the personal feud between the Cardinal Heroes -- or their lives. Fitoria will support Naofumi and Filo for now, but if they fail her, they might pay for it with their lives. Rising of the Shield Hero's queen has no time for games. Home TV TV News Moon Knight Stars Say Khonshu Was a 'Diva' Behind the Scenes    Moon Knight Stars Say Khonshu Was a 'Diva' Behind the Scenes  By Benjamin Wasserman Published 1 day ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Moon Knight’s Oscar Isaac, Ethan Hawke, and May Calamawy discuss the process behind developing the personality of their divine co-star Khonshu.                 Warning: The following contains spoilers for Episodes 1 and 2 of Moon Knight, now on Disney+.Gods often have an attitude and, according to the cast of Moon Knight, Khonshu is no exception.  Speaking to IGN, Oscar Isaac, May Calamawy, and Ethan Hawke jokingly opened up about whether the Egyptian Moon god responsible for Moon Knight's suit was a "diva behind the scenes." Calamawy stated "No, I felt like I just wasn't putting up with his crap in front of the camera," while Isaac explained how the show managed to mo-cap Khonshu's body. "We had a really great actor named Kareem, and he had to wear this big green pole over his head," said Isaac. The star, who plays protagonist Steven Grant, acknowledged that "there were... tricky, tricky days to shoot those because sometimes you just can't help but look at someone's face when they're talking and to kind of change your mind, to just look up like three feet above them onto it, to a green pole with ping pongs on them."  RELATED: Is Khonshu A Friend or Foe?    Similarly, Hawke made a joke about the Egyptian pantheon's attitudes before getting serious and admitting his fondness for Khonshu's visual design. "I love all that kind of mysticism and the special effects... I'm super interested in all that stuff and I get a huge kick out of it," Hawke said. "The finished version has F. Murray Abraham doing the voice, and he's always been one of my favorites." First appearing in 1980's Moon Knight #1, Khonshu is a member of the alien Ennead race whom Ancient Egyptians worshiped as deities, thus inspiring their classic mythology. The Disney+ show's Khonshu has mostly stayed loyal to his comic design, appearing as bird skull-faced entity dressed in bandages and carrying a crescent moon staff. As Marc Specter reveals in the Moon Knight Episode 2, "Summon the Suit," his role as Khonshu's avatar is to "protect the vulnerable and deliver Khonshu's justice to those who hurt them." Despite partnering with Marc, Khonshu is vocally disdainful of Steven Grant, one of the hero's alters, who was previously oblivious to his dissociative identity disorder and blamed his frequent blackouts on sleepwalking.  Related: Moody Moon Knight Promo Takes Marc Spector's Fight to the Pyramids Moon Knight's conflict revolves around Steven becoming unwittingly involved in Marc and Khonshu's war against cult leader Arthur Harrow, who seeks to awaken the latter's rival deity Ammut. Harrow reveals that he was a previous avatar of Khonshu and is quite familiar with the god's temperament. Furthermore, as Marc discloses to Steven, Khonshu has been considering Marc's wife Layla El-Faouly for his next avatar, explaining his reason for abandoning her and fleeing to London. New Moon Knight episodes premiere on Wednesday on Disney+  Source: YouTube                  Is Moon Knight a Hero? Home Anime Spy x Family Creator Debuts Dynamic New Art Celebrating the Anime’s Premiere    Spy x Family Creator Debuts Dynamic New Art Celebrating the Anime’s Premiere  By Michael Lacerna Published 22 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Spy x Family creator Tatsuya Endo shares several new pieces of art to celebrate the premiere of the series' anime adaptation.                 Spy x Family released new art to celebrate the anime's successful premiere.  The Spy x Family TV series made its long-awaited premiere on April 9, and to celebrate, several new pieces of art by creator Tatsuya Endo were released. The first image comes from the anime's official Twitter account, which shared a dynamic new image of the Forger family reaching for the TV remote, presumably to watch their own show. The second image and third images were shared by Endo on his personal Twitter account, and depict Anya Forger watching TV and then taking a nap afterwards. RELATED: Spy x Family's Premiere Introduces the World's Most Adorably Awkward Father-Daughter Duo              Spy x Family tells the story of a super spy known only by his codename, Twilight. When his latest mission requires him to pretend to be a regular family man in order to get close to his next target, Twilight takes on the alias "Loid Forger," adopts a daughter, Anya, and quickly enters into a shotgun marriage with a seemingly normal file clerk named Yor. Unfortunately for the new Mr. Forger, his new family has secrets of their own: his wife lives a double-life as a femme-fatale assassin, and his daughter possesses psychic powers that immediately clue her in on her new parents' dangerous professions.  The series was originally created by Endo in 2019, when it debuted as an exclusive title for Shonen Jump+, the digital manga spinoff of Shueisha's popular Weekly Shonen Jump magazine. The series has since become one of the service's biggest hits, with over 12 million copies in circulation worldwide. In addition to its runaway commercial success, the manga has been well recieved by critics as well, and was nominated for an Eisner Award in 2021. RELATED: Spy x Family Crafts a Heartfelt Adaptation of Tatsuya Endo's Beloved Manga The new anime was recently voted the most anticipated show of the spring 2022 season and premiered in Japan to strong ratings. The show features an all-star voice cast, including Takuya Eguchi (Haikyuu!!), Atsumi Tanezaki (Mob Psycho 100) and Saori Hayami (Kakegurui). The anime is directed by Kazuhiro Furuhashi, who previously worked on shows such as Le Chevalier D'eon and Mobile Suit Gundam Unicorn. Production in the series is being handled as a collaboration between Wit Studio, which previously worked on the first three seasons of Attack on Titan and the acclaimed Ranking of Kings, and CloverWorks, the studio behind last season's biggest surprise hit, My Dress-Up Darling.  The Spy x Family anime is being simulcast on Crunchyroll. Endo's original manga is available in English from VIZ Media. Home Anime The 10 Best Anime Couples Of All Time, Ranked    The 10 Best Anime Couples Of All Time, Ranked  By Derek DeSantis Published 20 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Anime has produced some of the most romantic and heartbreaking relationships in animation history.                  Anime is a medium that stretches across different genres and demographics. The most popular anime in the world range from battle shonen to psychological thrillers. But regardless of the genre, most anime indulge in familiar tropes and subplots.  RELATED: 10 Romance Anime Critics Actually Loved No matter what anime is being discussed, there's a near certainty that at some point, one or many of the characters will end up with a romantic storyline. These plots can take center stage or stay on the sidelines, but they are responsible for giving fans some of the most iconic, romantic couples in fictional history.  10          Bakuman: Takagi And Kaya Are Middle School Sweethearts                 Bakuman is a unique addition to the Shonen Jump lineup as a competitive, battle shonen story about the creation of battle shonen manga. It depicts the artistic duo responsible for creating Death Note in a fictionalized setting where the two compete with other mangaka to become the highest-selling and most successful artists in Shonen Jump.  But no shonen anime would be complete without a bit of romance. Bakuman's healthiest couple is Takagi and Kaya. Sweethearts since middle school, the two struggled at times but never forgot their love for each other and stuck it out to the very end.  9          Steins;Gate: Okabe And Kurisu Overcame Their Differences                 Steins;Gate is a sci-fi thriller that follows a group of ragtag scientists as they invent the world's first time machine. It's a harrowing tale with twists and turns that'll captivate and confuse fans. But at the core of this anime is a romantic story between Kurisu and Okabe. These two scientists couldn't be more different, with one having a true academic background and the other having been through the wild internet world. But together they overcame those differences and formed an iconic pair that anime fans love.  8          Death Note: Light And Misa Are A True Power Couple                 The term "best" can mean a lot of different things. While anime's best couples are pairs that fans find touching and emotionally fulfilling, some couples become iconic for how troublesome they are. Light and Misa may be the villains of their story, but they form a problematic duo that managed to shake up the entire world. RELATED: 10 Worst Anime Couples Who Can't Stop Fighting With Each Other Together, the two of them were behind the largest string of serial murders and massively affected the world's average crime rates. They may not be as lovable as many other couples, but they were effective.  7          Hunter X Hunter: Meruem And Komugi Died In Each Other's Arms                 The Chimera Ant arc is one of the most philosophically deep and important arcs in anime. Highly regarded as one of Hunter X Hunter's highest achievements, the Chimera Ant arc introduced the characters Meruem and Komugi. While Meruem remained the final antagonist of the arc, his bond with Komugi garnered immense empathy from viewers. The two died in each other's company as they slowly withered away from poison, playing one final game of Gungi. It's a devastating scene that proves even villains have heart.  6          Yuri On Ice: Yuri And Victor Are A Rare Case Of Maturity In Anime                 Yuri on Ice is a sports drama that follows an aging figure skater making his last attempts to prove himself on the international stage. To do so, Yuri recruits the world-famous Russian skater, Victor Nikiforov. With Victor's help, Yuri learns to overcome his feelings of insecurity and embraces a style of skating that highlights his innate beauty. Yuri on Ice is a sensual anime that explores complex emotions and a heartwarming romance between two athletic titans. Fans were overwhelmed with love when they saw Yuri and Victor kiss for the first time.  5          Yu Yu Hakusho: Yusuke And Keiko Are A Classic Shonen Couple                 Yu Yu Hakusho was one of the all-time classic shonen anime that many '90s kids grew up with. As one of the first anime to find its audience in the West, Yu Yu Hakusho had a strong impression on the current anime landscape. RELATED: 5 Harsh Realities Of Dating A Tsundere (& 5 Perks) While the anime is not without mistakes, most notably a somewhat weak final arc, most fans can admit that Yusuke's budding relationship with his childhood best friend Keiko is one of the most heartwarming and enviable romances in all of anime.  4          Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood: Edward And Winry Are Relationship Goals                 When it comes to battle shonen anime, many fans complain that female characters are underutilized and reduced to stereotypical, boring archetypes. Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood defies these criticisms by presenting one of the most narratively interesting and capable women in anime history, Winry Rockbell. While Winry does fulfill the romantic interest role for the main character, fans find thier relationship more mature than almost any other battle shonen anime. Winry and Edward are constantly labeled as one of anime's best couples.  3          Beastars: Legoshi And Haru Are An Unorthodox Romantic Pairing                 Beastars is one of the freshest new anime to come out within the past 5 years. While the concept of an anthropomorphized animal society is far from unique, Beastars manages to impress with its grounded sociological dynamics and refreshingly authentic character types. RELATED: 10 Anime Relationships That Deserve A Second Chance The story follows Legoshi and Haru as they come to terms with their romantic feelings for each other in a world that does not want a wolf and rabbit to be in love. Their story is brutally complicated but continues to charm fans to their peculiar dilemma.  2          Bloom Into You: Yuu And Touko Explore The Complex Nature Of Love                 Bloom Into You is a yuri anime that follows an aromantic young girl as she slowly grapples with the affection of one of her upperclassmen. Yuu is a painfully relatable character for anime fans who don't feel and can't understand romantic attraction. Bloom Into You tackles complex character dynamics, balancing the delicate emotions of a partnership between two people who want vastly different things from each other. While Yuu and Touko's partnership feels troubling at times, it never loses its sense of authenticity or commitment to the character's realistic feelings.  1          Naruto: Minato And Kushina Brought Sensitivity And Compassion To Naruto Romance                Naruto is plagued with criticisms towards its treatment of female characters. Women in Naruto are often sidelined compared to their male counterparts and are almost always reduced to frustrating archetypes that bring nothing new to anime storytelling. While Kushina falls in one of these usual archetypes for female characters, her relationship with Minato brought a sensitivity and compassion to the Naruto world that still managed to feel unique. This pair defined the Naruto series and became one of the most iconic couples in only a few short moments.                  8 Romance Anime Characters Who Ended Up Choosing Nobody  Read Next     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email    Related Topics  Anime anime Hunter X Hunter Naruto Shippuden death note Beastars     About The Author      Derek DeSantis                                     (53 Articles Published)       More                     From Derek DeSantis          Popular                     TV News   Percy Jackson's Live Action Disney+ Series Casts Its Star                      Nerd Culture   EXCLUSIVE: Transformers Debuts Wild Rider, Blitzwing Legacy Figures                      TV News   Stranger Things Creators Compare Season 4 to Game of Thrones                       Nerd Culture   Namor Cosplayer Brings Marvel's Sub-Mariner to Life                      TV Features   Bobby Hill’s Serious King of the Hill Episodes Are the Most Relatable                      TV Features   Outer Range's Shaun Sipos Teases the Good, the Bad and the Supernatural        Comic Book Reviews Comic Book Previews                      Image Comics' Radiant Red #2 Comic Review   Image Comics Release: 04.6.22                      Below Sycamore #1 Comic Review                        DC's Suicide Squad #14 Comic Review   DC Comics Release: 04.5.22                      Marvel's X-Force Annual #1 Comic Review   Marvel Comics Release: 04.6.22                      DC's Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1 Comic Review   DC Comics Release: 04.5.22                      Sakamoto Days Feels Like It Comes From the '90s - Home Comics Comic Book Reviews DC's Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1 Comic Review    DC's Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1 Comic Review  By Sayantan Gayen Published 4 days ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Terry McGinnis deals with the aftermath of Bruce Wayne’s death in Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1, a techno-modern action-packed issue.                                    Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1   Writer  Collin Kelly, Jackson Lanzing    Artist  Max Dunbar, Sebastian Cheng    Letterer  Aditya Bidikar    Publisher  DC Comics    Price  3.99    Release Date  2022-04-05      Bruce Wayne is dead, leaving Terry McGinnis to uphold the legacy of Batman. This is the first time Terry will have to go solo without the voice of his mentor and friend guiding him. During the events of Batman: Urban Legends #7, published by DC Comics last year, Bruce's pacemaker overloads and kills him, but not before he gives Terry his blessings. An enraged Terry tears the city apart in search of the culprit, only to come back home to the Batcave and realize it was Gotham itself that killed Bruce. A super-intelligence, dubbed the Neo-Gotham, now runs through the city's veins and has identified Batman as the virus. Written by Collin Kelly and Jackson Lanzing with artwork from Max Dunbar and Sebastian Cheng and lettering by Aditya Bidikar, Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1 starts a new chapter for Batman.  Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1 pits Terry McGinnis against the sentinel AI avatar of Gotham City. It has been two months since Neo-Gotham woke up and killed Bruce Wayne and two months since Terry started his solitary crusade against the criminal element. However, he is nowhere near cleansing the streets of crime or turning Gotham on his side. To add to the predicament, Bruce's other legacy, the Wayne-Powers corporation, is now run by a former crook, the Holographic Man. Batman investigates the new CEO when he comes across a cargo ship carrying drug supplies. As he is about to jump into action, an agent of Neo-Gotham stops him in his tracks. Now he has two choices: stand down or join Gotham in her upcoming genocide.  RELATED: DC's Batman: Beyond the White Knight #1 Comic Review                 Terry McGinnis is at a crossroads in his life. With his mentor gone and the number of allies dwindling, Terry is trying hard to keep the peace in his city while desperately clamoring to keep Bruce's legacy intact. Loneliness has gripped him as Batman is spread thin over Gotham putting out fires. Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1 envisions a different kind of Gotham, one that is aesthetically techno-modern but has transcended the barriers of technology and is now turning on its own citizens. The only person in its way is its sworn protector. A linear narrative with a heavy emphasis on its protagonist, the story progresses through Terry's point of view, using first-person narrative boxes to explore his inner feelings and resolve. The debut issue of this Batman Beyond reboot does well to provide exposition through character interactions. The action kicks up a notch in the latter half, with new adversaries rearing their heads.  Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1 showcases a neon-lit, futuristic Gotham City filled with high-tech machinery and ultramodern urban architecture. Artist Max Dunbar uses crisp lines and elaborately detailed backgrounds to infuse the pages with animated energy that gives off a cartoonish vibe. To not take away from the seriousness of the plot, Dunbar employs a variety of techniques, from glaring close-ups to brooding panels. However, what catches the eye are the full-length splash pages that frame the characters, new and old, in their natural element. Meanwhile, the coloring best brings out the neo-futuristic aesthetic of the book. Colorist Sebastian Cheng's use of alternate tones of colors to create light and shadow gives depth to the artwork. Cheng douses the Gotham sky in an eternal shade of soothing purple, creating a great contrast with Batman's black and red.  RELATED: DC's Batman: Killing Time #2 Comic Review                 From the get-go, Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1 never seems to let its foot off the gas, continuing the momentum and suspense that started in the pages of Batman: Urban Legends #7 all the while adding new flavors into the mix as the story progresses. A fan-favorite character, Terry McGinnis is at a rough spot in his life, and it is only going to get tougher. After years of listening to an old grumpy man's voice in his head, Terry has developed an unhealthy habit of speaking to an absent father figure. His grief gives the overlaying narration a melancholic tune. As times get tough, Terry must brace himself as Gotham comes for all that stand against it. Batman Beyond: Neo-Year #1 ends on a narrative hook that is bound to bring readers back for more. Home Comics Comic Book Previews Kaiju Score: Steal From the Gods #1    Kaiju Score: Steal From the Gods #1  By Liam Nolan Published Mar 21, 2022     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   AfterShock Comics presents a preview of Kaiju Score: Steal From the Gods #1, by James Patrick and Rem Broo.                                    Kaiju Score: Steal From the Gods #1   Artist  Rem Broo    Cover Artist  Juan Doe, Rem Broo    Letterer  Dave Sharpe    Price  4.99    Publisher  AfterShock Comics    Release Date  2022-04-13    Writer  James Patrick      Michelle is back, she has her own crew, and she's making her own rules. Unfortunately, her tendency for getting into hot water still remains, and her involvement in that now-infamous job in Florida, known as the Kaiju Score, is haunting her in many different ways. It's about to put her on a collision course with a new job, new characters, and – of course – new monsters. The second volume of the critically acclaimed, best-selling KAIJU SCORE (optioned-by-Sony Pictures) is here, and just like last time, not everyone will get out alive.  Written by James Patrick (CAMPISI: THE DRAGON INCIDENT, Grimm Fairy Tales, Death Comes to Dillinger, The Monsters of Jimmy Crumb) and illustrated by Rem Broo (The End Times of Bram and Ben, Terminal Protocol), KAIJU SCORE: STEAL FROM THE GODStakes the crazy of the first volume to new heights of WTF! Home Comics Comic Book Reviews Below Sycamore #1 Comic Review    Below Sycamore #1 Comic Review  By Dustin Holland Published 20 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   D.A. Medina, 3858 and Fernando Kern's Below Sycamore #1 introduces readers to a fascinating world of drugs, demons and desperate people.                  In 2019, writers D.A. Medina and 3858 teamed up to create a play about demonic figures walking the earth and the cyclical nature of addiction. After the success of their their theatrical debut, Medina and 3858 recruited artist Fernando Kern and designer Zueoner to help them develop the play into a comic series. Soon, Below Sycamore attracted the attention of actor Danny Trejo and rapper Mr. Criminal, whose likenesses are featured prominently throughout the series. Below Sycamore #1 is an intriguing first issue that sets the stage for an exciting, poingant series.   Bellow Sycamore #1 follows two young men, Chucho and JD as they struggle to find their way in the world. The two friends are altar boys at their local church, but JD also works for a fearsome drug dealer, known as Grumpy. He does his best to find a balance between these two elements of his life, but as his situation becomes increasingly dangerous, it looks like he will have to make a difficult decision. As JD tries to navigate his perilous path, the two young men are followed by supernatural creatures who are hellbent on protecting them.  Related: AWA's The Joneses #1 Comic Review                Medina and 3858 introduce a wide variety of characters in this first issue. While Chucho and JD steal the show, the writers introduce the audience to priests, gangsters, addicts in recovery and corrupt police. This inclusive and expansive view of the neighborhood helps make Chucho's world feel lived in while laying the foundation for an intricate plot. The otherworldly elements of Below Sycamore #1 add a sense of mystery to the proceedings and contrast with the numerous Christian themes and images to build tension. Medina and 3858 include various opposing forces -- all revolving around drugs and addiction to present an empathetic and exciting exploration of the topic.   Kern's artwork helps Medina establish a fast pace bouncing between various characters without leaving the reader behind. His character designs are naturalistic but cartoony enough to be distinctive. His subtle, almost mundane costume designs make the supernatural characters stand out and appear particularly out of place against the otherwise normal background. Kern uses this sort of contrast masterfully throughout Below Sycamore #1. JD's body language changes drastically from when he is at church to when he is on the street. Similarly, scenes of violence are fast brutal interruptions of the otherwise calm, steady pace of the story.   Related: Vault's West of Sundown #1 Comic Review                There's nothing particularly subtle about Below Sycamore #1. The comic definitely wears its heart on its sleeve, but Medina, 3858 and Kern work together to create a really compelling first issue. Their characters feel like normal, everyday people which makes the frightening situations they find themselves in all the more emotionally intense. Readers looking for solid crime fiction with a paranormal twist or a thoughtful exploration of addiction's impact on communities will be delighted by the first issue of Below Sycamore. Home Comics Comic Book Reviews Below Sycamore #1 Comic Review    Below Sycamore #1 Comic Review  By Dustin Holland Published 20 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   D.A. Medina, 3858 and Fernando Kern's Below Sycamore #1 introduces readers to a fascinating world of drugs, demons and desperate people.                  In 2019, writers D.A. Medina and 3858 teamed up to create a play about demonic figures walking the earth and the cyclical nature of addiction. After the success of their their theatrical debut, Medina and 3858 recruited artist Fernando Kern and designer Zueoner to help them develop the play into a comic series. Soon, Below Sycamore attracted the attention of actor Danny Trejo and rapper Mr. Criminal, whose likenesses are featured prominently throughout the series. Below Sycamore #1 is an intriguing first issue that sets the stage for an exciting, poingant series.   Bellow Sycamore #1 follows two young men, Chucho and JD as they struggle to find their way in the world. The two friends are altar boys at their local church, but JD also works for a fearsome drug dealer, known as Grumpy. He does his best to find a balance between these two elements of his life, but as his situation becomes increasingly dangerous, it looks like he will have to make a difficult decision. As JD tries to navigate his perilous path, the two young men are followed by supernatural creatures who are hellbent on protecting them.  Related: AWA's The Joneses #1 Comic Review                Medina and 3858 introduce a wide variety of characters in this first issue. While Chucho and JD steal the show, the writers introduce the audience to priests, gangsters, addicts in recovery and corrupt police. This inclusive and expansive view of the neighborhood helps make Chucho's world feel lived in while laying the foundation for an intricate plot. The otherworldly elements of Below Sycamore #1 add a sense of mystery to the proceedings and contrast with the numerous Christian themes and images to build tension. Medina and 3858 include various opposing forces -- all revolving around drugs and addiction to present an empathetic and exciting exploration of the topic.   Kern's artwork helps Medina establish a fast pace bouncing between various characters without leaving the reader behind. His character designs are naturalistic but cartoony enough to be distinctive. His subtle, almost mundane costume designs make the supernatural characters stand out and appear particularly out of place against the otherwise normal background. Kern uses this sort of contrast masterfully throughout Below Sycamore #1. JD's body language changes drastically from when he is at church to when he is on the street. Similarly, scenes of violence are fast brutal interruptions of the otherwise calm, steady pace of the story.   Related: Vault's West of Sundown #1 Comic Review                There's nothing particularly subtle about Below Sycamore #1. The comic definitely wears its heart on its sleeve, but Medina, 3858 and Kern work together to create a really compelling first issue. Their characters feel like normal, everyday people which makes the frightening situations they find themselves in all the more emotionally intense. Readers looking for solid crime fiction with a paranormal twist or a thoughtful exploration of addiction's impact on communities will be delighted by the first issue of Below Sycamore. Home Comics Comic News EXCLUSIVE: I Hate This Place Trailer Showcases Demons, Aliens and Terrifying Horror    EXCLUSIVE: I Hate This Place Trailer Showcases Demons, Aliens and Terrifying Horror  By Brandon Schreur Published 1 hour ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   CBR has the exclusive trailer premiere for Image Comics and Skybound Entertainment's upcoming I Hate This Place supernatural horror series.                 A new trailer for Image Comics and Skybound Entertainment's upcoming I Hate This Place is packed with aliens, demons, monsters and more terrifying horror.  CBR has the exclusive trailer premiere for I Hate This Place, a new supernatural horror series from writer Kyle Starks (Assassin Nation, The Six Sidekicks of Trigger Keaton), artist Artyom Topilin (Ice Cream Man Presents: Quarantine Comix Special), colorist Lee Loughridge (Deadly Class, The Good Asian) and letterer Pat Brosseau (Birthright, Manifest Destiny). The trailer sees a couple looking for a fresh start as they inherit a family farm. Once they arrive, the two quickly learn that the place is home to all kinds of supernatural terrors they could have never been prepared for. These terrors include all kinds of ghastly demon-like creatures capable of causing copious amounts of bloodshed.   RELATED: The Logic of Lettering Unites Superman, Spider-Man and Many Image Comics    The official synopsis for I Hate This Place #1 reads, "After inheriting a farmhouse, Trudy and Gabby are ready to start the next chapter of their lives together...except it's already home to a mysterious force that's attracted ghosts, aliens, and all kinds of supernatural beings for decades. Now, Gabby and Trudy must play by the 'house rules' in order to survive the most frightening place on Earth." X-Men writer Gerry Duggan praised the series for having "everything you want in a comic, and it should come with a neck brace as it shifts from crime, horror and romance at whiplash speeds."  RELATED: Image Comics' Science Fiction Gem Saga Is Setting Up An Epic Confrontation Each issue of I Hate This Place will have open-to-order covers with clean and explicit options available for fans and retailers -- I Hate This Place and F*ck This Place, which is the series' original title. Both versions will be available at comic book shops on May 18. Standard editions will also be available on digital platforms, including Amazon Kindle, Apple Books, comiXology and Google Play. "We’ve heard the requests from fans and retailers to have different versions of I Hate This Place #1 that meet their needs, so we’ve decided to offer a variety of options for each issue of the series,” said Skybound Entertainment editor Jon Moisan previously told Image Comics. “Kyle, Artyom and Lee have created a captivating horror series that really speaks to the fears we have about our uncertain futures, and we know you’re going to fall in love with the first issue, no matter the title on the cover.”  I Hate This Place #1 comes from Starks, Topilin, Loughridge and Brosseau, with cover art by Topilin and Loughridge. The issue releases May 18 from Image Comics and Skybound Entertainment. Home TV TV Features Sorry, The Walking Dead’s Midseason Finale Was a Waste of Time    Sorry, The Walking Dead’s Midseason Finale Was a Waste of Time  By Blake Hawkins Published 1 day ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The Walking Dead's "Acts of God" had the potential to be a very good episode, but certain shortcomings made it fail to reach that potential.                  The following contains spoilers for The Walking Dead Season 11, Episode 16, "Acts of God," which aired Sunday, April 10, on AMC.   Most fans of The Walking Dead would agree that, so far, Season 11 has been a success. The Reaper story arc might have been stretched out too far, but other than that, everything has been riveting. The Commonwealth presented everyone with the challenges that arise while living in safety, and Josh Hamilton has been brilliant as the uber-villainous Lance Hornsby. Even Negan showed a new side of himself by apologizing for his most vile act.  With all of that, fans were more than ready for the Season 11B midseason finale. With Leah as a bounty hunter, Maggie desperate to defend her people and Hornsby ready to unleash hell, “Acts of God” was set up for success. Unfortunately, it ended up falling far short of viewers' high expectations for several different reasons. RELATED: The Walking Dead’s Power Family Is About To Be Exposed          Leah’s Death Was Predictable and Unrealistic                 When Lance hired Leah, it was obvious that she wasn’t going to survive the altercation. However, the way the show handled it was a disappointment. Leah was touted as a military contract killer. That means she should have killed Maggie on sight, not just tied her up in a cabin. On top of that, she definitely should have been able to tie a better knot. Her background as a military expert felt even more forced after the episode, even taking into account that in a world where zombies are walking around, not everything is going to be realistic.  RELATED: The Walking Dead's Jeffrey Dean Morgan Shares Melancholic Wrap Photo          The Plot Armor Was Better Than Real Armor                 After the ordeal at Riverbend, it was only a matter of time before Hornsby decided to get rid of Daryl, Gabriel and Aaron. They knew it and the fans knew it. So when the Commonwealth soldiers fanned out and left the trio in a junkyard, it wasn’t a surprise. Then the soldiers proved their lack of aim -- just like Star Wars’ Stormtroopers -- because the three of them emerged nearly unscathed. Viewers didn't want any of their heroes to die, but it felt like the situation warranted something bigger happening. These were supposed to be trained soldiers, but they all died at the hands of a trio that hasn’t handled guns in years.  RELATED: The Walking Dead's Newest Couple Is the Show's Cutest Yet          Marco Was A Scapegoat                In a midseason finale, the stakes have to be high, and given that this is the last season, The Walking Dead should be starting to whittle down some characters. Someone had to die, and if it couldn’t be Aaron or Gabriel, it had to be Marco. He was the least important character aligned with Maggie, so when he stood up and acted like everything was fine, everyone expected him to be shot in the head. If the audience can’t remember a character’s name, they probably won’t last long.  RELATED: The Walking Dead Dropped Its First F-Bomb in Four Years          Hornsby’s Physical Transformation Was Too Corny                Lance Hornsby was always two-faced, but him literally becoming Two-Face from Batman was jut too much. Daryl only skimming his face was worth an eyeroll because if it had been any other character, Daryl wouldn’t have missed. Hornsby’s slow-motion coin flips were also unnecessarily dramatic. No one cared if he kills the people at Oceanside because almost all of them were unnamed anyway. That lack of connection with his potential victims made the episode's cliffhanger not impactful at all.  RELATED: The Walking Dead's Norman Reedus Celebrates Series Wrap With Touching Video          A Lack of Screen Time for Certain Characters Was Surprising                Daryl and Maggie needed to take center stage in "Acts of God," but certain characters have been snubbed for a lot of the season. Yumiko, Magna, Dianne and Judith got almost no screen time at the Commonwealth. Back at the communities, Virgil, Luke and Gracie saw no screen time whatsoever. Obliviously, the series can’t feature everyone in every episode, but some of them should have gotten a bit more of a look. As a whole, Season 11B was successful and paved the way for an exciting conclusion to The Walking Dead. “Acts of God” wasn’t bad, but it should have improved on the above aspects and then it would have been the important episode that it wanted to be. As it stands, it was a fine conclusion, but one full of untapped potential.  To see how the series concludes, watch The Walking Dead Season 11C. It will likely air later this year on AMC and be available to stream early on AMC+. Home Anime Spy x Family's Premiere Introduces the World's Most Adorably Awkward Father-Daughter Duo    Spy x Family's Premiere Introduces the World's Most Adorably Awkward Father-Daughter Duo  By Hilary Leung Published 1 day ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The most anticipated anime of the season has premiered, and Episode 1 lived up to its hype.                  The following contains spoilers for Spy x Family Episode 1, “Operation Strix,” now streaming on Crunchyroll.   It's too early to say with only one episode out, but Spy x Family might go down in history as one of the few anime adaptations that lived up to the hype. In fact, the adaptation took the source material and breathed life into it in a way that made the characters feel real and human. Episode 1 has gorgeous animation, the voices for both Twilight and Anya perfectly fit their characters and the music adds the right weight of emotionality.  The story isn't simple per se, as the premise has the potential to branch out into a number of different avenues, but it has a charming and heartwarming simplicity about it that easily sweeps viewers into the story. Spy x Family's basis is about a fake family who all have secrets to hide and reasons for hiding them -- even their last name, Forger, is very tongue in cheek -- but at its heart, it's about three individuals who have always longed to have a family and have found one in each other. RELATED: Spy x Family Crafts a Heartfelt Adaptation of Tatsuya Endo's Beloved Manga                Twilight is the best spy in the world. Not only is he able to lie without batting an eye but his disguises are flawless. Unfortunately, his latest mission, Operation Strix, is an important one in maintaining peace between the East and the West, but it demands that he play a role even he's not sure he can pull off: a father.  As Loid Forger, he goes to a nondescript orphanage to adopt a six-year-old who will be able to attend Eden Academy, the same school that the son of his target Donovan Desmond attends. There, he meets Anya, who seems to fit every single requirement: she's six years old, she can read and write and she can solve a difficult crossword puzzle in no time. The secret? Anya is a telepath. One of the great appeals of Spy x Family is its humor. Loid and Anya have a bit of an awkward start to their new father-daughter relationship. Loid is so out of his depth as a dad that he's utterly bewildered by Anya's behavior. It doesn't help that Anya is reading his thoughts and trying her best to accommodate them. As a spy, Loid is always thinking a few steps ahead, and poor Anya often misinterprets them with her childish logic. For example, she immediately hides when Loid starts looking out for enemies, or she tells Loid all of her likes and dislikes in an effort to help him "understand" her. Behind all the hilarious moments of Anya trying to follow Loid and please her new dad, she's insecure about her place in the Forger family.  RELATED: Spy x Family: Anya Faces Off Against the Manga's Version of Umbridge                Even though Loid picked Anya for the sole reason of her ability to read and write (never mind how she read his mind in order to do so), there's an undeniable bond between the two. Loid has taken on the identity of Twilight to preserve peace between Ostania and Westalis, while Anya had been experimented on in a facility. One of the new things that the anime added to the episode occurs near the end, when Loid finds Anya waiting for him even though he had directed her to the police station. As Anya hugs his leg, rubbing her face on it to comfort herself and confessing that she wants to go back to their home, Loid recalls Franky's words about Anya's past. She had been adopted four times and returned every single one of them, and has consequently had four different names: Anya Williams, Anya Levski, Anya Roche and Anya Klein. Every other thing about her identity had been wiped clean.  Even though he wasn't aware of it, maybe that's why Loid picked Anya and why he went to save her even though he knew that he could simply find another child to adopt for his mission. He saw himself in her. They're both orphans who have had multiple identities throughout their lives. The entire reason he chose to be a spy was so there would be no more orphans like him, and here was Anya who desperately wanted a family. And maybe, although he won't admit it, he wanted one too. Poor Loid is now experiencing the exhaustion that all first-time parents have. The after-credits scene after Anya thwacks Loid's face with the mail is one of the sweetest moments in the episode. Watching her face light up and then seeing her snuggle up next to Loid while he sleeps is utterly adorable. The Forgers may be a dysfunctional family, but after seeing Loid and Anya, how can viewers not root for them? Home Anime Naruto: How Sakura Overcame Ino's Craftiest Technique in the Chunin Exam    Naruto: How Sakura Overcame Ino's Craftiest Technique in the Chunin Exam  By Patrick Morris Published 3 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The battle between Sakura and Ino was a highlight of the Chunin Exams, but how did Sakura manage to overpower Ino's most mysterious technique?                 No great shonen anime is complete without a tournament arc. Yu Yu Hakusho has both the Dark and Demon World Tournaments, Jujutsu Kaisen has the "Kyoto Goodwill Event" arc and Dragon Ball has more than any viewer would care to count. The international, multigenerational sensation Naruto is no exception.  Naruto's "Chunin Exams" tournament arc played host to some of the most brutal battles in anime, not the least of which was the showdown between the series' female lead Haruno Sakura and her rival Yamanaka Ino. Sakura and Ino had competed fiercely with one another -- particularly for the affections of Uchiha Sasuke -- throughout the series. As such, it was only natural that the two should meet in a head-to-head battle in the preliminary rounds of the Chunin Exams tournament. RELATED: A Naruto Reddit Theory Explains How the Chunin Exam Arc Helps Character Development                 Fought over the course of episodes 41 and 42 of Season 1, the match between Ino and Sakura proved to be one of Naruto's most gripping. Not only did it reveal more of Sakura and Ino's shared complex history, but it also represented a pivotal moment in Sakura's development.  During the match, Ino attempted to use her signature Mind Transfer Jutsu against Sakura. The Mind Transfer Jutsu is a technique that allows the caster to occupy and control the body of an opponent. Ino's plan was to use the technique to take over Sakura's body and force her to concede the match. However, Sakura overcame the allegedly unbreakable technique and went on to battle Ino to a draw. RELATED: How Naruto’s Backstory Is Similar to Orient Protagonist Musashi's                 How was it that Sakura overpowered the Mind Transfer Jutsu? After all, the technique worked well enough in Episode 24, when Ino used it to review and copy Sakura's answers to the written exam, as well as against the formidable Sound ninja Kin Tsuchi in the Forest of Death. Is it possible that Naruto's sideline encouragement empowered Sakura, or is shonen anime plot armor to thank for coming to Sakura's rescue?  It's true that Sakura acknowledges and appreciates Naruto for his words of support in the episode immediately following her bout with Ino. That said, Sakura's victory over Ino's Mind Transfer technique is thanks to her own strength. RELATED: Boruto FINALLY Introduces Naruto's Most Underrated - and Ominous - Upgrade                 As she attempted to take over Sakura's body, Ino was overpowered by Sakura's hidden inner self. This "Inner Sakura" (very vocally) represents Sakura's truest feelings. In the earlier episodes of Naruto, "Inner Sakura" frequently appears as a running gag, forcefully expressing feelings completely contrary to those Sakura has just displayed, punctuated by her catchphrase "Cha!" Indeed, by virtue of her being completely internalized, it would seem that Sakura was somewhat ashamed -- even embarrassed -- by this "Inner Sakura."  While "Inner Sakura's" appearance may seem like a well-placed throwback to the earliest Naruto episodes -- or worse, comically-employed plot armor -- it's a moment that signifies the cumulative fruition of Sakura's character growth throughout the narrative. RELATED: How Tall Are the Naruto Characters?                 By utilizing a facet of her personality that may once have been thought of as a shortcoming, Sakura displayed remarkable personal strength. Rather than squash or ignore her inner self -- the literal voice of her most authentic emotions-- Sakura embraced it, and in so doing became stronger physically and psychologically.  Indeed, Sakura is the character who displayed the most significant development throughout the "Chunin Exams" arc. Of the core cast, Sakura was the one who recognized and confronted her intrinsic flaws the most successfully. Consequently -- and even though their fight is ruled a draw -- Sakura's remarkable growth is on full display in her defeat of Ino's powerful Mind-Transfer Jutsu.
