Home Anime Naruto: How Sakura Overcame Ino's Craftiest Technique in the Chunin Exam    Naruto: How Sakura Overcame Ino's Craftiest Technique in the Chunin Exam  By Patrick Morris Published 3 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The battle between Sakura and Ino was a highlight of the Chunin Exams, but how did Sakura manage to overpower Ino's most mysterious technique?                 No great shonen anime is complete without a tournament arc. Yu Yu Hakusho has both the Dark and Demon World Tournaments, Jujutsu Kaisen has the "Kyoto Goodwill Event" arc and Dragon Ball has more than any viewer would care to count. The international, multigenerational sensation Naruto is no exception.  Naruto's "Chunin Exams" tournament arc played host to some of the most brutal battles in anime, not the least of which was the showdown between the series' female lead Haruno Sakura and her rival Yamanaka Ino. Sakura and Ino had competed fiercely with one another -- particularly for the affections of Uchiha Sasuke -- throughout the series. As such, it was only natural that the two should meet in a head-to-head battle in the preliminary rounds of the Chunin Exams tournament. RELATED: A Naruto Reddit Theory Explains How the Chunin Exam Arc Helps Character Development                 Fought over the course of episodes 41 and 42 of Season 1, the match between Ino and Sakura proved to be one of Naruto's most gripping. Not only did it reveal more of Sakura and Ino's shared complex history, but it also represented a pivotal moment in Sakura's development.  During the match, Ino attempted to use her signature Mind Transfer Jutsu against Sakura. The Mind Transfer Jutsu is a technique that allows the caster to occupy and control the body of an opponent. Ino's plan was to use the technique to take over Sakura's body and force her to concede the match. However, Sakura overcame the allegedly unbreakable technique and went on to battle Ino to a draw. RELATED: How Naruto’s Backstory Is Similar to Orient Protagonist Musashi's                 How was it that Sakura overpowered the Mind Transfer Jutsu? After all, the technique worked well enough in Episode 24, when Ino used it to review and copy Sakura's answers to the written exam, as well as against the formidable Sound ninja Kin Tsuchi in the Forest of Death. Is it possible that Naruto's sideline encouragement empowered Sakura, or is shonen anime plot armor to thank for coming to Sakura's rescue?  It's true that Sakura acknowledges and appreciates Naruto for his words of support in the episode immediately following her bout with Ino. That said, Sakura's victory over Ino's Mind Transfer technique is thanks to her own strength. RELATED: Boruto FINALLY Introduces Naruto's Most Underrated - and Ominous - Upgrade                 As she attempted to take over Sakura's body, Ino was overpowered by Sakura's hidden inner self. This "Inner Sakura" (very vocally) represents Sakura's truest feelings. In the earlier episodes of Naruto, "Inner Sakura" frequently appears as a running gag, forcefully expressing feelings completely contrary to those Sakura has just displayed, punctuated by her catchphrase "Cha!" Indeed, by virtue of her being completely internalized, it would seem that Sakura was somewhat ashamed -- even embarrassed -- by this "Inner Sakura."  While "Inner Sakura's" appearance may seem like a well-placed throwback to the earliest Naruto episodes -- or worse, comically-employed plot armor -- it's a moment that signifies the cumulative fruition of Sakura's character growth throughout the narrative. RELATED: How Tall Are the Naruto Characters?                 By utilizing a facet of her personality that may once have been thought of as a shortcoming, Sakura displayed remarkable personal strength. Rather than squash or ignore her inner self -- the literal voice of her most authentic emotions-- Sakura embraced it, and in so doing became stronger physically and psychologically.  Indeed, Sakura is the character who displayed the most significant development throughout the "Chunin Exams" arc. Of the core cast, Sakura was the one who recognized and confronted her intrinsic flaws the most successfully. Consequently -- and even though their fight is ruled a draw -- Sakura's remarkable growth is on full display in her defeat of Ino's powerful Mind-Transfer Jutsu. Home Anime Tokyo 24th Ward: The Biggest Plot Twists That Defined the Anime    Tokyo 24th Ward: The Biggest Plot Twists That Defined the Anime  By Louis Kemner Published 16 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   This short cyberpunk shonen anime is packed with mind-bending plot twists.                 Tokyo 24th Ward is an exciting sci-fi shonen anime series from the Winter 2022 anime season, and it recently reached its thrilling conclusion in Episode 12, early in the spring 2022 season. Despite its short length, the story of Tokyo 24th Ward is an intriguing and thought-provoking one with densely-packed plot twists and revelations throughout.  This is the tale of Tokyo's troubled island ward, where the state surveillance system named Hazard Cast is causing no end of controversy as the ward government tightens its grip on the populace. It's up to protagonist Aoi Shuta and his friends Koki and Ran to save the day and prevent his island ward home from spiraling into cyberpunk-style anarchy and despair. What plot twists await Shuta in Tokyo 24th Ward? RELATED: Platinum End's 5 Most Shocking Plot Twists & How They Defined the Story          When Shuta, Koki & Ran Gained The Power Of Cipher                In the series' double-length premiere episode, the hero, Shuta Aoi, was wallowing in despair over failing to save his friend Suido Asumi in an elementary school fire when a brand-new disaster struck. Shuta's friend Mari was stuck on train tracks and was about to get run over, and Shuta saw those grisly events for himself when he and his friends gained the ability to see into the near future with Cipher. Most importantly, this "Quirk" was a gift from Asumi's digital ghost, and she asked her three friends to somehow save the future. This rebooted Shuta's failed career as an amateur hero, and he, Koki and Ran used their cyberpunk gifts to save Mari's life.          When The False Villain Carneades Appeared                After Shuta and his friends failed to save the day during their second superhero mission, the mysterious masked villain Carneades appeared on TV, claiming responsibility for the disaster at the GourFes event. However, this was a ruse. Carneades was actually Koki's ally Tsuzusagawa, who used this persona to hide the fact that the all-seeing KANAE system was glitching badly. Tsuzusagawa didn't want mayor Suido Gori to learn the truth, so she bought herself time with the Carneades character, and Shuta learned this for himself when he confronted her on the roof of the Cornucopia building one day -- although there was more to it than that.  RELATED: The Technology of Tokyo 24th Ward's Cyberpunk Future, Explained          When Shuta's Team Learned The Truth Of Asumi & KANAE                The KANAE surveillance system had a dire secret: the entire thing was run with the remains of Asumi herself, with her biological brain allowing the high-tech system to process incredible amounts of data and accurately predict the future. Mayor Suido himself knew this, but what he didn't know was that his daughter's conscience was still intact inside the system, meaning her transhumanist digital ghost could think for itself. Asumi was in agony, so Tsuzusagawa gave Shuta and Koki the mission to somehow put an end to this and save Asumi from her cyberpunk fate. The entire ward depended on it as the KANAE controversy worsened.          When Kunai Was Killed For His Role In Drug D & Attempted Terrorism                Mayor Suido wanted an excuse to increase his use of KANAE in Tokyo's 24th ward, so he had his associates exploit Ran's friend Koki, creating something known as "Drug D." This was a warped version of Kunai's high-tech therapy system, and it tricked everyone into thinking a powerful drug was being spread across the ward. That would create the perfect excuse to tear down the ward's shantytown and replace it with a casino monitored by KANAE, and Kunai fought back by attempting to blow up a ship owned by the person who created Drug D -- a certain Howard Win. Then, SARG assassinated Kunai right before Ran's eyes, and that drove a deep wedge between the rebellious Ran and his government-supporting friend Koki.          When Suido Kanae Was Killed In A Flashback                Another major plot twist took place not in the present, but in the past. A flashback shed some light on how the KANAE system came to be, and it was all based on Suido Kanae and her associates. Kanae dreamed of a system that could help protect the people of the ward, but she died in a stabbing incident, and her grieving husband, future mayor Suido Gori, took action. He grew bitter and vowed to use technology to maintain order in the ward to honor his wife's memory, no matter how many lines were crossed. Eventually, when his daughter Asumi was all but dead after the fire, Gori used her body to complete the KANAE system and prevent such disasters from taking place in the ward ever again. However, this was never what Suido Kanae wanted. Mayor Suido himself knew this, but what he didn't know was that his daughter's conscience was still intact inside the system, meaning her transhumanist digital ghost could think for itself. Asumi was in agony, so Tsuzusagawa gave Shuta and Koki the mission to somehow put an end to this and save Asumi from her cyberpunk fate. The entire ward depended on it as the KANAE controversy worsened.          When Kunai Was Killed For His Role In Drug D & Attempted Terrorism                Mayor Suido wanted an excuse to increase his use of KANAE in Tokyo's 24th ward, so he had his associates exploit Ran's friend Koki, creating something known as "Drug D." This was a warped version of Kunai's high-tech therapy system, and it tricked everyone into thinking a powerful drug was being spread across the ward. That would create the perfect excuse to tear down the ward's shantytown and replace it with a casino monitored by KANAE, and Kunai fought back by attempting to blow up a ship owned by the person who created Drug D -- a certain Howard Win. Then, SARG assassinated Kunai right before Ran's eyes, and that drove a deep wedge between the rebellious Ran and his government-supporting friend Koki.          When Suido Kanae Was Killed In A Flashback                Another major plot twist took place not in the present, but in the past. A flashback shed some light on how the KANAE system came to be, and it was all based on Suido Kanae and her associates. Kanae dreamed of a system that could help protect the people of the ward, but she died in a stabbing incident, and her grieving husband, future mayor Suido Gori, took action. He grew bitter and vowed to use technology to maintain order in the ward to honor his wife's memory, no matter how many lines were crossed. Eventually, when his daughter Asumi was all but dead after the fire, Gori used her body to complete the KANAE system and prevent such disasters from taking place in the ward ever again. However, this was never what Suido Kanae wanted. Home Movies Movie Features Sonic the Hedgehog 2: Is It Too Early for [SPOILER]?    Sonic the Hedgehog 2: Is It Too Early for [SPOILER]?  By Michael Guterres Published 15 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Sonic the Hedgehog 2 introduced plenty of exciting new characters, but it may be too early for one in particular.                  The following article contains spoilers for Sonic the Hedgehog 2, now playing in theaters.   Sonic the Hedgehog 2 sped into theaters last Friday to much excitement from fans. And it’s easy to see why; between the introduction of Knuckles and Tails, the high-octane action and a bombastic finale, the film does a great job of upping the stakes and keeping fans on their toes. But the film's mid-credits scene was particularly noteworthy for its introduction of another fan-favorite character: Shadow the Hedgehog.  Shadow debuted in the 2001 game Sonic Adventure 2, which explored his history as the genetic experiment of Gerald Robotnik, the grandfather of Eggman. Since then, Shadow has served as one of Sonic’s biggest rivals -- a dark mirror of the blue hedgehog with murkier morals and a more tragic past. He’s also had ups and downs, between his own solo game, appearances in various cartoons and plenty of good and bad stories in the Archie and IDW comics. But despite him being a staple of the franchise for years, it may be too early to bring him into the movies. RELATED: Sonic the Hedgehog 2 Outdid Spider-Man: No Way Home in One Massive Way                  The first thing to remember about Shadow’s introduction is that it came a decade after Sonic’s first game. That’s ten years of developing Sonic as a character, introducing him to new friends and having him face off against deadly enemies. A status quo had been set by this point, especially for Sonic himself, and throwing Shadow into the mix did nothing but develop his character further and give him and his world a new direction to go. But the world of the Sonic the Hedgehog movies and the cast of characters inhabiting it have only just begun, and Shadow is a game-changer -- he can and will uproot everything fans know so far.  There’s also the issue of Shadow’s status as Sonic’s rival, a role currently filled by Knuckles in the films. In a way, Knuckles was one of Sonic’s first proper counterparts in the games. The two had similar motives, sure, but their differing personalities meant that the two clashed as often as they cooperated. And over time, that rivalry faded as the two underwent arcs that brought them closer together, leaving room for new rivals. But the films haven’t had time for that yet; Sonic and Knuckles may be on the same side by the end of the film and may even be friends, but their personalities are still likely to be a source of conflict in the future. And by introducing Shadow so soon, the films run the risk of brushing Knuckles to the wayside, which, given how positive fan reactions have been to the character, seems like a poor decision.  RELATED: Sonic 2 Runs Circles Around the Original With Colorful Chaos                 And on top of all that, there's still the question of how the introduction of Shadow can naturally build upon the events of the previous two films. The first movie introduced the idea of Sonic and Eggman’s rivalry, ending with Sonic beginning to find a new family while Eggman descended into madness. The second film built more on those ideas, introducing new characters, diving deep into Robotnik’s hatred of Sonic and worldbuilding through concepts like the Chaos Emeralds and Master Emerald. In fairness, the Emeralds are used prolifically in Shadow’s debut game. And though not the main focus of Eggman’s plan, which is to take over the world, his hatred of Sonic does shine through at various points. But the plot of Adventure 2 is a change to the status quo -- it doesn’t just build upon what’s come before, it changes it. But the films haven’t gotten to that point yet, leaving Shadow’s introduction and main story feeling premature. If there’s one thing the Sonic the Hedgehog movies are good at, it’s making the game characters compelling and well-written. They’ll likely do the same with Shadow, but they still run the risk of introducing him before it's time, which could easily derail the story they’ve been trying to tell.  To see Shadow's film debut, Sonic the Hedgehog 2 is now playing in theaters.                   Sonic 2 Director Addresses the Potential of a Super Smash Bros. Home Anime Spy x Family Reveals English Cast and Earlier Than Expected Premiere Date    Spy x Family Reveals English Cast and Earlier Than Expected Premiere Date  By Michael Lacerna Published 19 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Crunchyroll reveals the first casting details for the English dub of Spy x Family, alongside an early premiere date for the dubbed version.                 Crunchyroll revealed new details about Spy x Family's English dub.  The company announced on its website that the English dub of the highly-anticipated Spy x Family anime will premiere on its streaming service on April 16. The English edition of the show will star Alex Organ (My Hero Academia) as Agent Twilight/Loid Forger, Natalie Van Sistine (Full Dive: This Ultimate Next-Gen Full Dive RPG Is Even Shittier than Real Life!) as Yor Forger and Megan Shipman (Akebi's Sailor Uniform) as Anya Forger. The show will also feature the talents of Anthony Bowling (The Devil is a Part-Timer), who will portray Frankie, an informant who assists Twilight with his missions.  RELATED: Spy x Family's Premiere Introduces the World's Most Adorably Awkward Father-Daughter Duo In addition to revealing the first members of the show's English cast, Crunchyroll also announced that fans will be able to get an early preview of the English dub. The first episode of the dubbed series will be streamed on Crunchyroll's official Twitch channel on April 15 at 1:00 p.m. PT, one day before it becomes available on the streaming service. The subtitled version of the series premiered on April 9 to generally positive reviews and strong ratings in Japan. Series creator Tatsuya Endo celebrated the show's successful launch by releasing several new illustrations of the Forger family. The show is being directed by Kazuhiro Furuhashi, who previously worked on Mobile Suit Gundam Unicorn. The anime is being produced as a collaboration between Wit Studio, the animation company responsible for the first three seasons of Attack on Titan and the TV adaptation of Vinland Saga, and CloverWorks, the studio behind Wonder Egg Priority and last season's biggest surprise hit, My Dress-Up Darling.  RELATED: Spy x Family: Twilight's Backstory Reveals His Complicated Relationship With His Father Spy x Family is set in a Cold War-inspired world and focuses on the latest mission of the super spy known only by his codename, Twilight. In order to get close to his next target, Twilight takes on the identity of Loid Forger, a seemingly normal family man. Unbeknownst to Twilight, his new family have secret identities of his their own: his seemingly demure wife, Yor, is actually a deadly assassin, while his adorable daughter Anya is an escaped experiment with psychic abilities. The series was first published as an exclusive for the Shonen Jump+ digital manga platform in 2019. The series has since become one of the service's biggest hits, with over 12 million copies in circulation worldwide. In addition to its runaway commercial success, the manga has been well recieved by critics as well, and was nominated for an Eisner Award in 2021. The manga is available in English from VIZ Media. Home Anime Honeyworks: How to Get Started on the Music-Based Franchise    Honeyworks: How to Get Started on the Music-Based Franchise  By CBR Staff Published 26 minutes ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Heroines Run the Show has just started airing in the Spring 2022 anime season, but it's actually the latest installment of a much bigger universe.                 Heroines Run the Show has just begun airing as part of the packed Spring 2022 anime season, but believe it or not, it's the latest installment of a much bigger universe. So big, in fact, that it's been around for more than ten years.  Here's a quick run-down of the world spun by Honeyworks, and how newcomers and veteran fans alike can get started with each area of the sprawling anime, manga and music franchise. RELATED: Pokémon Live! Doc Explores How the Short-Lived Stage Musical Became Lost Media          Who and What Is Honeyworks?                 Honeyworks is an independent music circle comprised three core members: the composers Gom and Shito and their illustrator, Yamako. They got their start by producing music through the popular vocal synthesizing software, VOCALOID. They first started producing music in 2010 and released their first full album in 2011.  In 2014, the trio collaborated with the singer CHICO and formed the new unit CHICO with Honeyworks. They would go on to perform several opening and ending themes for a number of popular anime, including Haikyuu!!, Gintama and Magic Kaito. RELATED: Over a Decade On, Kimi ni Todoke is Still a Masterpiece of the Romance Anime Genre          Honeyworks' Connection to Famous Anime Voice Actors - and Hatsune Miku                Honeyworks have released numerous music videos since their debut, but their best-known works are part of a large, ongoing continuity titled Confession Executive Committee ~Love Series~. The series details the love lives of several different teenagers who all happen to attend the same high school. It brings focus to different kinds of love: romantic, platonic and even unrequited. The core cast consists of six characters: Miou, Haruki, Natsuki, Yuu, Souta and Akari, as they stumble through awkward confessions and first dates up to their graduation ceremony.  There is a proper order to watch the videos, and they can all be viewed for free on Honeyworks' official YouTube channel. Be warned, however: not all of the available videos have English subtitles. All the main characters have at least one song centered on them, starting with Love's Picture Book. The songs were initially performed by virtual singers, including GUMI, Hatsune Miku, Kagamine Len and vFlower. As the series gained more popularity, Honeyworks eventually switched to using human singers more often, managing to get well-known talents in the voice acting industry like Yuki Kaji, Haruka Toumatsu and Natsuki Hanae.  Confession Executive Committee ~Idol Series~ is both a spin-off and a sequel that takes place roughly a year after the cast of Love Series have graduated. It focuses on several up-and-coming idols as they juggle celebrity life with their own personal drama and a dash of romance. Characters from the Love Series make frequent appearances and while knowledge of their origins is recommended, it isn't necessary to fully enjoy this follow-up. Unlike its predecessor, there isn't a very clear starting point for the ~Idol Series~ music videos. While it's generally recommended to start with LIPxLIP's Romeo, most of the songs can be watched in any order.  RELATED: Komi Can't Communicate & Other Great High School Anime Streaming on Netflix          Where to Watch & Read Honeyworks' Anime & Manga Adaptations                There have been two film adaptations and an eight-episode anime based on Confession Executive Committee ~Love Series~. The first two films, I've Always Liked You and The Moment You Fall in Love, can be watched in release order followed by the anime, Our Love Has Always Been 10 Centimeters Apart. While the anime is available for streaming on Crunchyroll and Funimation, both films were removed from the Crunchyroll library in May 2021 and are currently unavailable for streaming or purchase.  As for the Confession Executive Committee ~Idol Series~, there has been a film adaptation that focuses on the idol unit LIPxLIP titled Kono Sekai no Tanoshimikata: Secret Story Film (How to Enjoy This World: Secret Story Film). The film has yet to be picked up for streaming by any platforms. Finally, the latest anime adaptation that started airing this Spring, Heroines Run the Show, acts as a direct sequel to the film and focuses on the idol unit's manager, the plucky country girl Hiyori. It is currently available for streaming on Crunchyroll. RELATED: What Music-Inspired Anime to Watch After takt op.Destiny                 In addition to all the anime adaptations, there have also been a number of novel and manga series, some either acting as direct adaptations of the source material or chronicling entirely new side stories. There are even a number of audio drama CDs, albums featuring all-new music performed by the anime's cast, and a mobile phone game that's still currently in service. Unfortunately, none of these supplemental materials have been officially licensed and translated outside of Japan. But possibly the most impressive piece of official media to have come out of this franchise would be the live concerts. The idol units created by Honeyworks appear on stage and perform via hologram projection, not unlike a typical Hatsune Miku concert.  Honeyworks has created a lovable shojo universe that seems to be growing bigger every year. There's a lot to dig into here, and this is just scratching the surface. But if one has the time and an insatiable hankering for something sweet and fluffy, then by all means, dig deeper. Home Anime Honeyworks: How to Get Started on the Music-Based Franchise    Honeyworks: How to Get Started on the Music-Based Franchise  By CBR Staff Published 26 minutes ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Heroines Run the Show has just started airing in the Spring 2022 anime season, but it's actually the latest installment of a much bigger universe.                 Heroines Run the Show has just begun airing as part of the packed Spring 2022 anime season, but believe it or not, it's the latest installment of a much bigger universe. So big, in fact, that it's been around for more than ten years.  Here's a quick run-down of the world spun by Honeyworks, and how newcomers and veteran fans alike can get started with each area of the sprawling anime, manga and music franchise. RELATED: Pokémon Live! Doc Explores How the Short-Lived Stage Musical Became Lost Media          Who and What Is Honeyworks?                 Honeyworks is an independent music circle comprised three core members: the composers Gom and Shito and their illustrator, Yamako. They got their start by producing music through the popular vocal synthesizing software, VOCALOID. They first started producing music in 2010 and released their first full album in 2011.  In 2014, the trio collaborated with the singer CHICO and formed the new unit CHICO with Honeyworks. They would go on to perform several opening and ending themes for a number of popular anime, including Haikyuu!!, Gintama and Magic Kaito. RELATED: Over a Decade On, Kimi ni Todoke is Still a Masterpiece of the Romance Anime Genre          Honeyworks' Connection to Famous Anime Voice Actors - and Hatsune Miku                Honeyworks have released numerous music videos since their debut, but their best-known works are part of a large, ongoing continuity titled Confession Executive Committee ~Love Series~. The series details the love lives of several different teenagers who all happen to attend the same high school. It brings focus to different kinds of love: romantic, platonic and even unrequited. The core cast consists of six characters: Miou, Haruki, Natsuki, Yuu, Souta and Akari, as they stumble through awkward confessions and first dates up to their graduation ceremony.  There is a proper order to watch the videos, and they can all be viewed for free on Honeyworks' official YouTube channel. Be warned, however: not all of the available videos have English subtitles. All the main characters have at least one song centered on them, starting with Love's Picture Book. The songs were initially performed by virtual singers, including GUMI, Hatsune Miku, Kagamine Len and vFlower. As the series gained more popularity, Honeyworks eventually switched to using human singers more often, managing to get well-known talents in the voice acting industry like Yuki Kaji, Haruka Toumatsu and Natsuki Hanae.  Confession Executive Committee ~Idol Series~ is both a spin-off and a sequel that takes place roughly a year after the cast of Love Series have graduated. It focuses on several up-and-coming idols as they juggle celebrity life with their own personal drama and a dash of romance. Characters from the Love Series make frequent appearances and while knowledge of their origins is recommended, it isn't necessary to fully enjoy this follow-up. Unlike its predecessor, there isn't a very clear starting point for the ~Idol Series~ music videos. While it's generally recommended to start with LIPxLIP's Romeo, most of the songs can be watched in any order.  RELATED: Komi Can't Communicate & Other Great High School Anime Streaming on Netflix          Where to Watch & Read Honeyworks' Anime & Manga Adaptations                There have been two film adaptations and an eight-episode anime based on Confession Executive Committee ~Love Series~. The first two films, I've Always Liked You and The Moment You Fall in Love, can be watched in release order followed by the anime, Our Love Has Always Been 10 Centimeters Apart. While the anime is available for streaming on Crunchyroll and Funimation, both films were removed from the Crunchyroll library in May 2021 and are currently unavailable for streaming or purchase.  As for the Confession Executive Committee ~Idol Series~, there has been a film adaptation that focuses on the idol unit LIPxLIP titled Kono Sekai no Tanoshimikata: Secret Story Film (How to Enjoy This World: Secret Story Film). The film has yet to be picked up for streaming by any platforms. Finally, the latest anime adaptation that started airing this Spring, Heroines Run the Show, acts as a direct sequel to the film and focuses on the idol unit's manager, the plucky country girl Hiyori. It is currently available for streaming on Crunchyroll. RELATED: What Music-Inspired Anime to Watch After takt op.Destiny                 In addition to all the anime adaptations, there have also been a number of novel and manga series, some either acting as direct adaptations of the source material or chronicling entirely new side stories. There are even a number of audio drama CDs, albums featuring all-new music performed by the anime's cast, and a mobile phone game that's still currently in service. Unfortunately, none of these supplemental materials have been officially licensed and translated outside of Japan. But possibly the most impressive piece of official media to have come out of this franchise would be the live concerts. The idol units created by Honeyworks appear on stage and perform via hologram projection, not unlike a typical Hatsune Miku concert.  Honeyworks has created a lovable shojo universe that seems to be growing bigger every year. There's a lot to dig into here, and this is just scratching the surface. But if one has the time and an insatiable hankering for something sweet and fluffy, then by all means, dig deeper. Home Anime Shield Hero: Raphtalia's Biggest Problem Is Also Her Most Personal One Yet    Shield Hero: Raphtalia's Biggest Problem Is Also Her Most Personal One Yet  By Louis Kemner Published 12 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Someday, Naofumi will have to leave this isekai world forever, and Raphtalia isn't ready for that.                 The Rising of the Shield Hero is a popular isekai anime series that recently returned in the Spring 2022 anime season for more adventures in the faraway Melromarc kingdom. By now, protagonist Iwatani Naofumi has formed an excellent party of adventurers to aid him, but eventually, they will have to say goodbye.  Since the beginning, Shield Hero has upturned one of isekai's core elements: the one-way trip. Heroes such as Rimuru Tempest and Ainz Ooal Gown have no hope of returning home, but once the Waves are over, Naofumi and the other Cardinal Heroes will be sent back home, never to return. And Naofumi's best friend, Raphtalia, isn't ready for this at all. RELATED: Meet The Rising of the Shield Hero's Main Characters          Why Raphtalia Must Learn To Say Goodbye                Naofumi's first party member in Shield Hero is the tanuki demi-human Raphtalia, whom he bought as a slave before appointing her as his party's main sword fighter. Soon, they formed a foster father/daughter dynamic, with each of them trusting and relying heavily on the other, even when the other party members such as Filo and princess Melty were added to the mix. Raphtalia is personally attached to Naofumi in the story of Shield Hero, but she is also aware that eventually, all four Cardinal Heroes will be sent back to Earth, never to return, and she is not prepared for this to happen.  Raphtalia is somewhat co-dependent on Naofumi, as he is the first person outside her home village to treat her well and value her. Naofumi gave Raphtalia a new purpose as a powerful warrior who can defend the innocent against the Waves, and Naofumi personally cares for all of Raphtalia's needs without hesitation. Naturally, this made Raphtalia strongly attached to him, and she panics slightly and is almost reduced to tears at the thought of them being forced apart in the future. Raphtalia does have the rebuilt Lurolona Village to appreciate, along with all its inhabitants, but Naofumi is another matter entirely. If Raphtalia doesn't want to totally break down when Naofumi is forced to leave, she must learn to form stronger bonds with her fellow natives and begin acting and thinking independently. For her own sake, she must gradually phase Naofumi out of her mind and replace him with her fellow villagers, Filo, princess Melty and the like, and make them the most important people in her heart instead.  Fortunately for Raphtalia, all those characters are equally fond of her and are worth Raphtalia's affection. They should provide a strong emotional cushion for Raphtalia when Naofumi returns to Earth, and Raphtalia could find the mental strength necessary to bid him farewell and move on without him. Even when Naofumi is gone, Lurolona and its demi-human denizens will remain, and they will need Raphtalia and vice versa. Naofumi must be Raphtalia's role model and inspiration, not her lover or perpetual guardian. Naofumi helped Raphtalia regain her freedom and encouraged her to face her painful past. Now she must honor Naofumi's gifts by learning how to live a post-Naofumi life when the time is right.  RELATED: Konosuba's Kazuma Vs Shield Hero's Naofumi: Who's the Unluckiest Isekai Hero?          What This Means For The Isekai Genre                This subplot in the story of Shield Hero has intriguing implications not just for Shield Hero itself but the subgenre of isekai as a whole. While isekai is not a formal literary genre, it is a well-established subgenre with some core rules to it ever since the early days of Sword Art Online, such as the main character having slim to no chance of returning home; often, the hero previously died or was summoned by magic to end up in the new world. It's not an absolute law that an isekai hero must remain trapped in this new world forever, but that is the norm, and perhaps some anime fans are getting tired of it. This often leads to abstract, open-ended stories where there is no real end goal, since the hero cannot return home under their own power, and such stories end up becoming typical power fantasies as a result.  That's where Shield Hero comes in, where the hero actually can return home under the right circumstances, and that gives him an end goal. He must survive and fight not just to defend the innocent but also to return home at last, and that gives Shield Hero a sense of direction. Most of all, this plot twist creates palpable personal stakes for Raphtalia and Naofumi, as Naofumi's eventual return home will drive them apart, and they must be prepared to say goodbye. Just the idea of that is heart-wrenching, and it sets an example that future isekai series could stand to follow. Home Video Games Critical Role - What Exandria Unlimited: Kymal's Ending Means for the Series' Future    Critical Role - What Exandria Unlimited: Kymal's Ending Means for the Series' Future  By Jennifer Melzer Published 19 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Critical Role's most recent installment of Exandria Unlimited: Kymal advanced the story, but there are plenty of threads left to fuel future episodes.                 Critical Role's Exandria Unlimited mini-campaign introduced fans to a whole new cast of player characters. It also brought an intriguing new Dungeon Master, Aabria Iyengar, with a completely different style than the Dungeons & Dragons play show's main DM, Matthew Mercer. Then, when EU regular Robbie Daymond was present for several episodes at the start of Critical Role's third campaign, fans weren't sure if he would become a permanent regular.  However, circumstances within the story eventually led to Daymond's Air Genasi Bard, Dorian Storm, fleeing the continent of Marquet in an airship with his fugitive brother, Cyrus. Returning to Tal'dorei, Dorian called out to old friends, the Crown Keepers, to help him find a way to pay his brother's massive bounty. At the end of the episode when Dorian and Cyrus left, Critical Role reassured fans that this would not be the last they saw of Daymond by announcing a special two-part episode of Exandria Unlimited titled "Kymal." Related: D&D's Call of the Netherdeep Shows How Rivals Can Improve the Game                 This announcement left fans to wonder how many other loose threads might be tugged in Kymal. One of the largest bits of unfinished business was the first major enemy the Crown Keepers made in Emon: Poska and the Nameless Ones. After stealing the Spider Queen's crown from Poska, the party fled from the city and embarked on their journey knowing the Nameless Ones would pursue. Not long after arriving in Kymal, they discovered the unaffiliated thieves guild was there as well, and they were doing everything in their power to take over the lawless casino town. Anjali Bhimani's Fire Genasi Monk, Fy'ra Rai, had initially left the group to search for her missing twin sister, Fy'ra Kai, but she heeded the call and returned to offer her aid to Dorian's cause. Her search for Fy'ra Kai seemed to be fruitless, but it wasn't long before she discovered her twin was there in Kymal -- and working with the Nameless Ones. This was just one of many important plot points from the initial mini-campaign that Kymal expanded upon, but when all was said and done, the thread was left wide open for future exploration.  Related: Why Poison Is Dungeons & Dragons' Worst Damage Type Additionally, Aimee Carrero's Warlock, Opal, had fully utilized the Spider Queen's Vestige of Divergence. The crown had obviously corrupted her in ways the old Opal would never stand for, but the power it offered was too enticing to refuse. The constant whispers of the Spider Queen now regularly accompanied those of Opal's Warlock patron, her twin sister Ted, whom the party actually fought in the final episode of the original mini-campaign.                As the party began plotting a heist to get their hands on the outrageous sum needed to clear Cyrus, they encountered a new ally. Critical Role's Exandria Unlimited mini-campaign introduced fans to a whole new cast of player characters. It also brought an intriguing new Dungeon Master, Aabria Iyengar, with a completely different style than the Dungeons & Dragons play show's main DM, Matthew Mercer. Then, when EU regular Robbie Daymond was present for several episodes at the start of Critical Role's third campaign, fans weren't sure if he would become a permanent regular.  However, circumstances within the story eventually led to Daymond's Air Genasi Bard, Dorian Storm, fleeing the continent of Marquet in an airship with his fugitive brother, Cyrus. Returning to Tal'dorei, Dorian called out to old friends, the Crown Keepers, to help him find a way to pay his brother's massive bounty. At the end of the episode when Dorian and Cyrus left, Critical Role reassured fans that this would not be the last they saw of Daymond by announcing a special two-part episode of Exandria Unlimited titled "Kymal." One of the largest bits of unfinished business was the first major enemy the Crown Keepers made in Emon: Poska and the Nameless Ones. After stealing the Spider Queen's crown from Poska, the party fled from the city and embarked on their journey knowing the Nameless Ones would pursue. Not long after arriving in Kymal, they discovered the unaffiliated thieves guild was there as well, and they were doing everything in their power to take over the lawless casino town. Anjali Bhimani's Fire Genasi Monk, Fy'ra Rai, had initially left the group to search for her missing twin sister, Fy'ra Kai, but she heeded the call and returned to offer her aid to Dorian's cause. Her search for Fy'ra Kai seemed to be fruitless, but it wasn't long before she discovered her twin was there in Kymal -- and working with the Nameless Ones. This was just one of many important plot points from the initial mini-campaign that Kymal expanded upon, but when all was said and done, the thread was left wide open for future exploration. The following contains spoilers for Episode 12 of Tokyo 24th Ward, "Youth 24th Ward," now streaming on Crunchyroll.   The bitter controversy over the oppressive KANAE surveillance system comes to a head in the final episode of Tokyo 24th Ward, when Shuta and his two friends reunite as the RBG squad to save the day once again as homegrown heroes. This is the mission that Shuta inherited from Chikushi, and he must see it through to the end for the entire ward's sake.  Most of all, Shuta must complete this mission for Suido Asumi's sake, with her being trapped inside the KANAE system as a transhumanist AI who suffers constant torment in the digital world. Asumi is convinced that the pain of paying the price for choosing a new future is too great to bear, but Shuta, Koki and Ran feel differently. They have shonen's power of friendship on their side. RELATED: Haikyuu!!'s Uplifting Ending, Explained                Episode 12 picks up right where Episode 11 left off, with Shuta, Koki and Ran reconciling their bitter differences to save their island ward home one last time as heroes gifted with the power of Cipher in their eyes. The three boys receive one last "trolley dilemma" scenario from Asumi via their superpowers, and they must choose to either expose KANAE's secrets and have the system shut down, or else use a module to rewrite it and have Asumi's transhumanist mind go to peaceful "sleep" in the system forever.  Either way, Asumi will be lost, but that is what she wants. Existing in this digital transhumanist state is agony for her, to the point where she glitches constantly. This is what prompted Tsuzusagawa to pose as "Carneades" the villain to explain KANAE's strange predictions, but now, a more permanent solution must be found. Shuta must make his most difficult decision of all. RELATED: Shield Hero: Naofumi Explores an Exotic New Kingdom in Season 2's Premiere                Shuta and his friends believe in the power of friendship, and they use it to meet Asumi directly, even though Asumi doesn't want to speak with them. In Asumi's mind, the sacrifices necessary to obtain a desired future are too much to bear, and compromise is impossible. By contrast, Shuta and his friends use both the power of friendship and faith in the future to face this dilemma anyway and make the right choice, even if they can't "cheat" and have things both ways to create a foolproof scenario. The boys understand that paying opportunity costs is a fact of life, and they have the courage to pay those costs if it means taking a chance on a better future.  No one, not even the RGB boys, can ever guarantee that their risky decisions will pay off and create the future that they want, but that isn't a problem for them, especially with the power of friendship on their side. To them, gambling on dilemmas and paying opportunity costs is simply proof that they are alive and in control of their lives, and that makes them happy. Asumi accepts this solution and bids her three friends a fond farewell, this time without any anguish or regrets. She fades away, and the KANAE system is shut down by a grieving Mayor Suido. The episode's falling action explains how the people of the 24th ward will take their future into their own hands without the need for all-seeing state surveillance systems, which ends the ward's current conflict peacefully. This also means that the entire ward's population can echo RBG's power of friendship and faith in the future, and everyone can step toward this future with confidence. The ward is more than its buildings or high-tech computers -- it's the people, and those people can be trusted with their own future. On that note, the cyberpunk story of Tokyo 24th Ward comes to a close. Home Anime Requiem of the Rose King's Censorship Hinders Progress on Important Conversations    Requiem of the Rose King's Censorship Hinders Progress on Important Conversations  By Hilary Leung Published 22 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Despite having a character who is intersex, Requiem of the Rose King's censorship makes it less than progressive.                  The following contains spoilers for Requiem of the Rose King, now streaming on Funimation, as well as discussion of sexual assault.   Censorship isn't anything new in the anime industry, especially when it comes to violence. Viewers have seen it happen in anime like Tokyo Ghoul with the censorship of Kaneki's torture scene, but other anime such as Attack on Titan have never shied away from showing gory scenes. However, Requiem of the Rose King, which likewise has its fair share of violent fight scenes (how could it not when it's set during the War of the Roses?) has been heavily censored to the point where there's hardly any animated movement at all. The anime tries to hide it by using color palettes that make scenes look intentionally artistic but it gets distracting.  Requiem of the Rose King is already breaking a lot of barriers with its concept. Rarely do viewers get to see an intersex character as the protagonist, and the anime could have started some important conversations around topics such as sexual violence while focusing on the LGBTQ+ community. Again, censorship between same-sex couples is familiar territory in anime and is often heavily implied, such as with the kiss scene in Yuri!!! on Ice. However, Requiem of the Rose King's treatment is blatantly disrespectful because the story is about Richard. By censoring his struggles with his body, the core of the story is lost.  RELATED: Requiem of the Rose King: Richard's Confession Ends in Heartbreaking Tragedy          The Kiss Scenes                 Richard's love for his father has always been apparent from the beginning. While his mother rejected him, his father had always been obvious in his unconditional support and love for his youngest son. Taunted by Margaret's lies about Richard's death, his father was killed and his head put on a stake for display. When at last Richard found his father, he kissed his head. While it's clear that this scene was censored due to its incestuous nature, plot-wise, this was also the turning point for Richard. Having been demonized and separated from the rest of his family by his mother, this moment with his father was for him alone.  In the last episode, Richard wavers between his love and hatred for Henry. At last, he decides to give him one last chance to accept him for who he is with both male and female body parts. For a split second, it looked as though he and Henry's story would have a happy ending as the two embrace, but the anime doesn't even show this. What's intended as an emotionally moving moment with the two finally giving in to their feelings and lust, made even more intense because both of them had their own personal reservations, was barely shown. The background had a kaleidoscope effect and when the two kissed, they turned into black silhouettes. Richard's knife blocked the viewers from seeing their lips touch.  However, when it came to Richard's kiss with Anne, that wasn't censored at all. The preference is clear as to what is 'appropriate' and what is deemed 'inappropriate.' Granted, at that time, same-sex relationships were looked down, but in this era and with the source material focusing on the LGBTQ+ community, it's disappointing that the studio took this route, as it unfortunately reinforces hetereonormative roles. By not censoring Richard's kiss with Anne, the adaptation affirms his gender identity as a man but discredits his feelings for men, thus reinforcing gender stereotypes and traditional societal norms.  RELATED: Why This Popular K-Drama Is an Error-Free BL Webtoon Adaptation          Portrayals of Sexual Violence                 Two key scenes have been understandably but heavily censored. The first is Richard's near sexual assault in Episode 2. He gets captured by a group of men when he was disguising himself as a woman, and his attacker only stops when he sees Richard's breasts. He flees, terrified. The second scene is Henry's sexual assault by Margaret, which is only hinted at in the anime. Henry's trauma from that event as well as bearing witness to his mother's infidelity are the reasons why he has repressed all of his desires and urges.  Sexual violence committed against men may not be as prevalent as that against women, but it still exists. Domestic violence is already underreported for both men and women, but when the victims are men, it's often even more so. The effects of what Henry has endured are shown clearly in his reactions to Richard, but this scene is glossed over and glimpsed only in quick flashes. Including a scene that focuses on Henry's emotional and physical abuse at the hands of his wife would have opened up a dialogue around domestic violence against men. It's undeniable that Requiem of the Rose King isn't so much a celebration of the LGBTQ community as much as it shows the sufferings of those who do not conform to gender binaries. It's why he feels that he can never be king and why he's unlovable. If the studio had been forward in its animation of Richard's body, it could have stirred an important wave in the conversation around acceptance. The following contains spoilers for Requiem of the Rose King, now streaming on Funimation, as well as discussion of sexual assault.   Censorship isn't anything new in the anime industry, especially when it comes to violence. Viewers have seen it happen in anime like Tokyo Ghoul with the censorship of Kaneki's torture scene, but other anime such as Attack on Titan have never shied away from showing gory scenes. However, Requiem of the Rose King, which likewise has its fair share of violent fight scenes (how could it not when it's set during the War of the Roses?) has been heavily censored to the point where there's hardly any animated movement at all. The anime tries to hide it by using color palettes that make scenes look intentionally artistic but it gets distracting.  Requiem of the Rose King is already breaking a lot of barriers with its concept. Rarely do viewers get to see an intersex character as the protagonist, and the anime could have started some important conversations around topics such as sexual violence while focusing on the LGBTQ+ community. Again, censorship between same-sex couples is familiar territory in anime and is often heavily implied, such as with the kiss scene in Yuri!!! on Ice. However, Requiem of the Rose King's treatment is blatantly disrespectful because the story is about Richard. By censoring his struggles with his body, the core of the story is lost. While his mother rejected him, his father had always been obvious in his unconditional support and love for his youngest son. Taunted by Margaret's lies about Richard's death, his father was killed and his head put on a stake for display. When at last Richard found his father, he kissed his head. While it's clear that this scene was censored due to its incestuous nature, plot-wise, this was also the turning point for Richard. Having been demonized and separated from the rest of his family by his mother, this moment with his father was for him alone.  In the last episode, Richard wavers between his love and hatred for Henry. At last, he decides to give him one last chance to accept him for who he is with both male and female body parts. The background had a kaleidoscope effect and when the two kissed, they turned into black silhouettes. Richard's knife blocked the viewers from seeing their lips touch.  However, when it came to Richard's kiss with Anne, that wasn't censored at all. The preference is clear as to what is 'appropriate' and what is deemed 'inappropriate.' Granted, at that time, same-sex relationships were looked down, but in this era and with the source material focusing on the LGBTQ+ community, it's disappointing that the studio took this route, as it unfortunately reinforces hetereonormative roles. He flees, terrified. The second scene is Henry's sexual assault by Margaret, which is only hinted at in the anime. Home Anime Jujutsu Kaisen April Fool’s Joke Inspires Real Anime Collaboration    Jujutsu Kaisen April Fool’s Joke Inspires Real Anime Collaboration  By Michael Lacerna Published 17 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Jujutsu Kaisen's absurd April Fool's joke becomes as a reality as the series begins an adorable new merch crossover with Pui Pui Molcar.                 Jujutsu Kaisen revealed a new collaboration the stop-motion series Pui Pui Molcar.  What started out as an April Fool's joke has now become a legitimate collaboration. The official Jujutsu Kaisen Twitter account announced that the series will cross over with the popular stop-motion animated series Pui Pui Molcar and revealed new art, which features the cast of Gege Akutami's dark-fantasy shonen series being paired up with their own hybrid guinea pigs/cars. The art work will appear on special merchandise, which will be released at a later date. The collaboration's official website also teases further announcements related to the crossover. RELATED: How Jujutsu Kaisen's Gojo and Nanami Embody the Elder Millennial Psyche          On April 1, Jujutsu Kaisen tweeted out an image of Masamichi Yaga, which was edited to look like he was holding Potato, the main character from Pui Pui Molcar. Yaga is the principal of Tokyo's Jujutsu High School, and possesses the ability to bring dolls to life with his special Cursed ability. Despite his intimidating appearance and demeanor, he frequently displays a preference for cute things, such as stuffed animals, which is probably the reason why he was the character who was picked to introduce the series' Molcar collaboration. Pui Pui Molcar premiered in Japan in early 2021 and is distributed internationally by Netflix. The series takes place in a world where humans drive sentient vehicles that resemble guinea pigs but have car-like qualities, such as wheels and doors. While intended for younger demographics, the series was a hit with fans of all ages, with praise going towards its adorably designed characters and simple humor. The 12-episode series was followed up with the release of a movie, entitled Tobidase! Narase! Pui Pui Molcar, which was released in Japan last July.  RELATED: Jujutsu Kaisen 0 Tops $30 Million, Leading Actors to Reveal Shockingly Low Pay Rates Jujutsu Kaisen, meanwhile, continues to be one of Japan's biggest anime and manga franchises. Gege Akutami's gritty work about the battle between sorcerers and cursed spirits was the best-selling manga of 2021, narrowly edging out Demon Slayer: Kimetsu No Yaiba. The series first movie, Jujutsu Kaisen 0, premiered in Japan last December, where it quickly became the highest-grossing film for 2021 in the region. The movie was released in North America last March, where it earned an addition $30 million USD. The movie has now pulled in over $180 million USD worldwide, making it one of the ten highest-grossing anime movies ever made. A second season of the anime series is scheduled to premiere in 2023.  The first season of Jujustu Kaisen is available for streaming on Crunchyroll. Gege Akutami's manga is available in English from VIZ Media. Pui Pui Molcar is available for streaming on Netflix. Home Anime Jujutsu Kaisen April Fool’s Joke Inspires Real Anime Collaboration    Jujutsu Kaisen April Fool’s Joke Inspires Real Anime Collaboration  By Michael Lacerna Published 17 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Jujutsu Kaisen's absurd April Fool's joke becomes as a reality as the series begins an adorable new merch crossover with Pui Pui Molcar.                 Jujutsu Kaisen revealed a new collaboration the stop-motion series Pui Pui Molcar.  What started out as an April Fool's joke has now become a legitimate collaboration. The official Jujutsu Kaisen Twitter account announced that the series will cross over with the popular stop-motion animated series Pui Pui Molcar and revealed new art, which features the cast of Gege Akutami's dark-fantasy shonen series being paired up with their own hybrid guinea pigs/cars. The art work will appear on special merchandise, which will be released at a later date. The collaboration's official website also teases further announcements related to the crossover. RELATED: How Jujutsu Kaisen's Gojo and Nanami Embody the Elder Millennial Psyche          On April 1, Jujutsu Kaisen tweeted out an image of Masamichi Yaga, which was edited to look like he was holding Potato, the main character from Pui Pui Molcar. Yaga is the principal of Tokyo's Jujutsu High School, and possesses the ability to bring dolls to life with his special Cursed ability. Despite his intimidating appearance and demeanor, he frequently displays a preference for cute things, such as stuffed animals, which is probably the reason why he was the character who was picked to introduce the series' Molcar collaboration. Pui Pui Molcar premiered in Japan in early 2021 and is distributed internationally by Netflix. The series takes place in a world where humans drive sentient vehicles that resemble guinea pigs but have car-like qualities, such as wheels and doors. While intended for younger demographics, the series was a hit with fans of all ages, with praise going towards its adorably designed characters and simple humor. The 12-episode series was followed up with the release of a movie, entitled Tobidase! Narase! Pui Pui Molcar, which was released in Japan last July.  RELATED: Jujutsu Kaisen 0 Tops $30 Million, Leading Actors to Reveal Shockingly Low Pay Rates Jujutsu Kaisen, meanwhile, continues to be one of Japan's biggest anime and manga franchises. Gege Akutami's gritty work about the battle between sorcerers and cursed spirits was the best-selling manga of 2021, narrowly edging out Demon Slayer: Kimetsu No Yaiba. The series first movie, Jujutsu Kaisen 0, premiered in Japan last December, where it quickly became the highest-grossing film for 2021 in the region. The movie was released in North America last March, where it earned an addition $30 million USD. The movie has now pulled in over $180 million USD worldwide, making it one of the ten highest-grossing anime movies ever made. A second season of the anime series is scheduled to premiere in 2023.  The first season of Jujustu Kaisen is available for streaming on Crunchyroll. Gege Akutami's manga is available in English from VIZ Media. Pui Pui Molcar is available for streaming on Netflix. Home Anime Your Name Creator Debuts Gorgeous First Trailer for New Movie, Suzume No Tojimari    Your Name Creator Debuts Gorgeous First Trailer for New Movie, Suzume No Tojimari  By Michael Lacerna Published 23 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Toho releases the haunting first trailer for Suzume No Tojimari, the latest work from Your Name and Weathering With You director Makoto Shinkai.                 Toho Co. Ltd. released the first trailer for Suzume No Tojimari, the new movie from Your Name director Makoto Shinkai.  The trailer introduces the movie's titular protagonist, Suzume, and the mysterious door that's at the center of the new film's plot. In addition to showcasing the new film's art style and animation, the trailer also reveals a Japanese premiere date for the movie, November 11. RELATED: Weathering With You's Big Your Name Connection, Explained    The film tells the story of Suzume, a 17-year-old girl who lives in a quiet small town in Japan's southern Kyushu island. Suzume discovers a door standing by itself in the middle of an abandoned and ruined building, and is compelled to open it. When she does, however, similar doors suddenly sprout up all over Japan, unleashing destruction and chaos wherever they appear.  As with many of his previous films, Suzume No Tojimari was both written and directed by Shinkai. The movie will see the celebrated director reunite with character designer Masayoshi Tanaka, who also served the same role on Your Name and Weathering With You. Takumi Tanji, who previously worked on Shinkai's 5 Centimeters Per Second and Children Who Chase Lost Voices, serves as the new film's art director. The animated film is being produced at CoMix Wave Films and Story Inc., with Toho distributing. RELATED: Your Name Stands Alone, But Fans Can't Let Go of Its Spinoff Potential Shinkai is one of the biggest names in the anime industry today, and his work is now frequently compared to Studio Ghibli's most well known auteur, Hayao Miyazaki. The director began his career at video game developer Falcom (Ys, Trails in the Sky) before moving on to anime with his directorial debut, the self-produced short She and Her Cat in 1999. Shinkai continued with the critically acclaimed Voices of a Distant Star in 2000 and his first feature length production, The Place Promised In Our Early Days, which was released in 2004 to widespread praise. Shinkai's breakout hit arrived in 2016 with the runaway success of the romantic comedy Your Name, which was the first non-Studio Ghibli anime film to earn over $100 million at the Japanese box office.  Details about the Suzume No Tojimari's international release, including an official translation for its title, have yet to be released. Your Name is currently available on DVD, Blu-ray and on-demand video from Funimation. Weathering With You is currently streaming on HBO Max. Distributor GKIDS recently announced that it has licensed four of Shinkai's earlier works and will be re-releasing the films on home video. Home Anime Sakamoto Days Feels Like It Comes From the '90s - and That's a Good Thing    Sakamoto Days Feels Like It Comes From the '90s - and That's a Good Thing  By Dallas Marshall Published 4 days ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Sakamoto Days has the feel of a manga from the '90s which may be off-putting to some, but there's more than enough hijinks and action to draw in fans.                 People who come from a history of crime have a lot to deal with. As they do their best to live a clean life, they sometimes have to deal with their former checkered lives, such as vengeful enemies, temptations to make "easy money" and old compatriots trying to force them back into their old ways. Most stories surrounding the theme of redemption and trying to escape a life of crime usually end in tragedy, a sad reminder that crime doesn't pay.  Today's manga is anything but sad, serious or a cautionary tale. Sakamoto Days, written by Yuto Suzuki and published by Viz Media, is a silly romp surrounding the life of a former hitman named Sakamoto. He was not just any hitman but the greatest the Yakuza have ever seen. Sakamoto was dashing, deadly and an expert killer. But after starting a family, he is now out of shape and the only trigger he pulls is the one on a bar code scanner since, after leaving his life of crime, he opened a convenience store with his lovely wife and child. While he may have left the underworld behind him, the underworld has not forgotten Sakamoto. A figure from his past comes to his store and makes a request: "return to the assassin world, or die!"  RELATED: The Director of Escaflowne Was Also Behind This Old-School Sci-Fi Crime Anim                The first noticeable factor about Sakamoto Days is that the art style is reminiscent of Viz Media's 1990s manga. The linework is softer and has less of the in-your-face aesthetics that cover the pages of modern-day manga. Sakamoto Days is a crime story that feels less like the gritty work of such dramas as Gangsta or Black Lagoon and more like a '90s staple such as Fushigi Yugi or Yu Yu Hakusho. While this may be off-putting to some fans of modern manga, the juxtaposition of softness mixed with the plot's challenging crime themes is an amusing dualism.  It is also funny that the jokes are thrown at the reader at a mile-a-minute pace alongside the action, which usually involves Sakamoto dealing with the day-to-day struggles of life like going to the grocery store is as severe as an assassination mission. After all, old habits die hard. However, despite its comedic tones, Sakamoto Days is for an older teen audience and features some violent scenes that should be avoided by the younger readers in the crowd. Luckily for our out-of-shape former criminal, he has a loving family that helps him keep on the straight and narrow. One of the best things about this manga is its main lead characters. Sakamoto's wife, Aoi, is his rock throughout and while she does know of his dark past, she sees the good in him and makes it her life's mission to guide her husband to be the best man he can be.  RELATED: The Best Free Short Manga on Manga Plus                 Love can change a man and Sakamoto Days reminds readers that even those who have the shadiest of histories can find redemption. So, instead of being a hitman for the Yakuza, Sakamoto utilizes his quick reflexes for customer care and community service, even if he gets carried away at times -- much to the chagrin of his wife and readers' amusement. As for some of the secondary characters in this manga, such as fellow former assassin-turned-convenience-store-clerk Shin, not many unique traits can be spoken for. Most of the side characters are, for lack of a better term, just there.  Sakamoto Days does not reinvent the wheel when it comes to comedy manga. The jokes are serviceable, complete with slapstick humor and visual gags that induce chuckles. The action scenes are well put together but will not blow readers' minds. But as a fun diversion with a somewhat retro aesthetic, Sakamoto Days does not need to be revolutionary to be entertaining and sets out to tell a silly story about redemption. It's the white cake of comedy manga: simple, somewhat sweet and direct. In a challenging world such as ours, sometimes folks need some comfort food -- even if it's all about crime and the bloodshed that comes with it. As for some of the secondary characters in this manga, such as fellow former assassin-turned-convenience-store-clerk Shin, not many unique traits can be spoken for. Most of the side characters are, for lack of a better term, just there.  Sakamoto Days does not reinvent the wheel when it comes to comedy manga. The jokes are serviceable, complete with slapstick humor and visual gags that induce chuckles. The action scenes are well put together but will not blow readers' minds. But as a fun diversion with a somewhat retro aesthetic, Sakamoto Days does not need to be revolutionary to be entertaining and sets out to tell a silly story about redemption. It's the white cake of comedy manga: simple, somewhat sweet and direct. In a challenging world such as ours, sometimes folks need some comfort food -- even if it's all about crime and the bloodshed that comes with it. Home Anime Top 10 Worst Ways To Die In Hunter X Hunter     Top 10 Worst Ways To Die In Hunter X Hunter   By Derek DeSantis Published 1 day ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Hunter x Hunter has some surprisingly gruesome scenes. Several characters lost their lives in the most horrific way.                  Hunter X Hunter is one of the oldest and most influential battle shonen currently in publication. Following the adventures of Gon and Killua, Hunter X Hunter explores the dangerous world of being a professional Hunter. Viewers have desperately wanted to travel to the Hunter X Hunter world to experience the rich culture and develop a unique Nen ability.  RELATED: 10 Times Hunter X Hunter Broke Our Hearts But while Hunter X Hunter may seem like an attractive destination spot on the surface, fans know just how ruthless this world can be. In Hunter X Hunter, death awaits around every corner.  10          Pitou Would Puppet Your Reanimated Corpse                 Hunter X Hunter has delivered on a number of climactic, emotionally devastating character deaths throughout its long tenure as an anime. But no character death compares to the heartbreak fans felt when they watched Gon's newest mentor die at the hands of Pitou during the Chimera Ant arc. Pitou was an unstoppable force of strength who acted with the curiosity and playfulness of a cat. But the last thing fans would want is to cross Pitou and end up as their reanimated corpse toy like Kite.  9          Hisoka Would Toy With You In A Hopeless Battle                 Veterans battle shonen fans know what it's like to wish they could travel into their favorite anime and test their might against some of the world's greatest battlers. Fans dream of becoming a professional Hunter and competing in Heaven's Arena for treasure and glory. But if there's one combatant no fan would dream of fighting, it would be the terrifying clown, Hisoka. Hisoka is a tactical mastermind with trickster abilities and a knack for punishment. Fighting him is a hopeless endeavor that would result in a slow, miserable death.  8          Children Are Prone To Tragic Death In Hunter X Hunter                 Hunter X Hunter has often stood out from its contemporaries in the shonen genre for its brutal and dark sequences. Hunter X Hunter is no stranger to grim depictions of death and torture. It's no surprise that in this world, even children are not safe. RELATED: 10 Responsible Anime Children Who Behave Like Adults Often in Hunter X Hunter, young characters are used to build empathy from the audience before tragically getting ripped away for a dramatic moment. Kurt and Reina are two of the most tragic examples as they were killed and fed to the Chimera Ant Queen at just nine and five years old. Easily one of the worst ways to die in the Hunter X Hunter universe would be as a small child trying to live a simple life.  7          Pokkle Had His Brain Probed After Death                 The Chimera Ant arc saw the devastation and destruction of many unique characters. Some of these deaths came quickly to build audience shock. But many were drawn out and slow to really hammer in the growing threat of the Chimera Ants. Pokkle's brain dissection by Pitou is one of the most horrifying images to ever come out of the anime. Seeing an old fan-favorite character get probed and prodded as a corpse was traumatizing to many viewers.  6          Feitan's Rising Sun Technique Can Melt An Army                 The Phantom Troupe was introduced during the Yorknew City arc. They immediately stood out as being some of the most powerful and mysterious villains created thus far.  RELATED: 10 Things In Hunter X Hunter That Aged Poorly While not every Troupe member was able to receive ample screen time during that initial arc, a few got reintroduced during the Chimera Ant arc as they traveled to defeat an Ant taking over their home city. During this sequence, Feitan unveiled a mesmerizing Nen ability that allowed the Troupe member to summon the heat and force of a sun. This is a death no fan would ever wish to experience.  5          If Poor Man's Rose Doesn't Kill You, The Radiation Will                 During the climax of the Chimera Ant arc, Meruem faced off with humanity's strongest warrior, Isaac Netero. It was a thrilling battle that had humankind's fate on the line. But fate seemed grim when Isaac Netero was bested and failed to defeat Meruem.  At that moment, however, the Poor Man's Rose bomb was activated. It was an explosion powerful enough to kill thousands. But even if one was lucky enough to survive as Meruem did, they'd fall victim to the bomb's radiation poison shortly after. A harrowing death that has no hope for escape.  4          Chrollo Has A Wide Variety Of Torture Techniques                 When the Phantom Troupe was introduced as the primary antagonists of the Yorknew City arc, Chrollo peaked audience intrigue for the new villain group. Chrollo is an enigmatic figure with a powerful Nen ability and the intelligence to wield it. Fans first glimpse at Chrollo's power was when Chrollo brutalized one of Hunter X Hunter's strongest assassins and tortured him with floating Nen fish that consumed his living body. This was a horrific ability that made Chrollo seem unstoppable.  3          Some Nen Users Make You Listen To How They'll Kill You                The implementation of vows and limitations is a unique aspect of Hunter X Hunter's power system. Nen is a complex system that allows a user to set their own limitation and in return gain a boost of power. One common rule that a Nen user might set is that their ability grows in strength if they explain it to their opponent. This creates a scary situation where one might hear their opponent describe their own ability and thus know the fight is about to get harder. In essence, a character might just hear their opponent spell out their death.  2          Chimera Ant Food Is Reborn Into The Species That Killed It                 The danger of the Chimera Ants is their ability to rapidly evolve based on the food that was eaten when they were born. This led to Chimera Ants developing unique abilities usually reserved for powerful predator animals, or even worse, Nen-wielding humans. RELATED: 10 Ways Hunter X Hunter Is Better When You’re An Adult But the worst aspect of being eaten by a Chimera Ant is that some semblance of a character's soul seems to pass on to the eventual Ant born from their body. That feeling of being reborn into the creature that killed and ate you is a unique horror that no living being could ever relate to.  1          Nanika's Mysterious Powers Can Wish Anyone To Death                Hunter X Hunter's final arc introduced Killua Zoldyck's younger sister. Alluka/Nanika is a mysterious entity that has the power to grant wishes and demand sacrifice. Those who ask a wish of the young girl can be granted infinite power, status, or wealth. But these wishes come at the cost of a proportionate sacrifice, often in the form of death.
